ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1—18-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authorization of cities to levy and collect taxes and fees, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 4, par. 1; specific business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq. 

Sec. 18-26. - Application. 
On or before January 1 of each year, every person who shall conduct or carry on any business, trade, profession or vocation within the corporate limits of the city must first, before engaging in this business, trade, profession or vocation, apply to the city clerk for a license and at the same time render to the city clerk the applicable license fee as hereinafter designated in this article. Each applicant for a city license shall disclose to the city clerk the type of business, trade, profession or vocation to be conducted; the locations thereof if more than one; the name and style thereof, and such other pertinent information as shall be necessary to carry out and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1001) 
Sec. 18-27. - Issuance. 
Upon receipt of the application of any person for a license to carry on any lawful business, trade, profession or vocation, not inconsistent with the laws of the United States, this state or the lawful ordinances of the city, and not contrary to or detrimental to the public health, morals and welfare of the citizens of the city, and when the application shall be accompanied by the prescribed fee and pertinent information required by this article, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue to this person a license for the conduct of the particular business, trade, profession or vocation to be carried on. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1002) 
Sec. 18-28. - Valid period. 
All licenses issued by the city clerk under the provisions of this article shall be valid from January 1 of the fiscal year when purchased and shall expire on December 31 of the same year. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1003) 
Sec. 18-29. - Display of licenses. 
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article must be prominently displayed in the place of business or office of the person to whom issued. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1005) 
Sec. 18-30. - Businesses having more than one location; multiple businesses at one location. 
All persons engaging in or carrying on any business, trade, profession or vocation at two or more disjoined locations shall be required to pay the applicable license fee, as hereinafter designated for each of the business locations or places. Any person who shall conduct more than one type of business, trade, profession or vocation at the same location or place of business shall be required to pay the applicable license fee for each business, trade, profession or vocation being conducted. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1006) 
Sec. 18-31. - Suspension; revocation. 
(a)  All licenses issued by the city clerk under the provisions of this article shall be subject to suspension by the mayor or revocation by the mayor and council upon the following terms and in the following manner: 
Upon information being furnished by any person that the holder of any license issued under the provisions of this article has, in connection with the business, trade, profession or vocation for which this license was issued, committed acts or is guilty of conduct contrary to the laws of the United States, the state, the city or is guilty of conduct contrary to the public health, morals, peace or welfare of the citizens of the city, it shall be the duty of the mayor to issue or cause to be issued a written notice, directed to the holder of the license, requiring the license holder to appear before the mayor and council and show cause why the license should not be revoked. The notice shall disclose the charges against the holder of the license and shall state the time, date and place of hearing, which hearing shall not be held less than five days nor more than 15 days from the date of receipt of the notice by the license holder. If, upon final hearing, the mayor and council shall, in accordance with the opinion they entertain as to the evidence and testimony submitted, believe that the license holder is guilty of the charges made, it shall be their duty to revoke the license of the person to whom it was issued or by whom it was held. 
(b)  The mayor may, if he shall deem it necessary for the protection or welfare of the people of the city, suspend the license of any person against whom charges have been made, pending final hearing on the issue of whether or not the license of this person should be revoked. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1008) 
Sec. 18-32. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person who shall conduct any business, trade, profession or vocation within the corporate limits of the city without obtaining a license and any person who shall fail to comply with or violate the several sections of this article shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct and upon each conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1011) 
Sec. 18-33. - Late payment of license fee. 
In addition to other penalties for the violation of this article, 20 percent of the license fee shall be added to this fee for each month that a business, trade, vocation or profession is carried on without a license. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1012) 
Sec. 18-34. - Transfer of license. 
A license issued under this article to any person may not be transferred to any other person doing business within the city, whether engaged in the same business or not. Should a person holding a valid business license issued hereunder change its place of business from one location to another, but continue to do the same business in the new location, and where such person maintains only the one place of business, then such license may be transferred from one place of business to another place of business. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1013) 
Secs. 18-35—18-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OCCUPATION TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 343, adopted Nov. 21, 1995, amended in its entirety Art. III (which had pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 337, adopted Dec. 9, 1994), §§ 18-45—18-75, to read as herein set out. Prior to the enactment of Ord. No. 343, Ord. No. 337, adopted Dec. 9, 1994, set out provisions which repealed the former Art. III, "License Fee Schedule." At the editor's discretion, the provisions of Ord. No. 337 were codified as a new Art. III. The former Art. III, §§ 18-56—18-58, derived from Code 1976, § 6-1009; Ord. No. 258, adopted Dec. 30, 1985; Ord. No. 271, adopted Feb. 17, 1987; Ord. No. 272, adopted Feb. 17, 1987; Ord. No. 282, adopted Nov. 17, 1987; Ord. No. 285, adopted Jan. 19, 1988; Ord. No. 286, adopted Feb. 16, 1988; Ord. No. 318, adopted Sept. 17, 1991; and Ord. No. 322, § I, adopted July 28, 1992. 

Sec. 18-45. - Occupation tax required; occupation tax required for business dealings in the city. 
For the year 1996 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for such business, trade, profession or occupation; which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the chief of police or this officer's deputies or to any police officer of the city, upon request. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-46. - Construction of terms; definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the term Sylvania is used herein, such term shall be construed to mean Sylvania, Georgia; wherever the term city is used herein, it shall be construed to mean Sylvania, Georgia. 
(b)  As used in this article, the term: 
(1)  Employee means the following: 
a.  Except as otherwise provided in subparagraph b. of this subsection, "employee" means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I. R. S. W-2 but not a form I. R. S. 1099. 
b.  An individual who performs work under the direction and supervision of one business or practitioner in accordance with the terms of a contract or agreement with another business which recruits such individual is an employee of the business or practitioner which issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I. R. S. W-2. 
(2)  Full-time employee means an employee who works 40 hours or more weekly, and, in addition, the average weekly hours of employees who work less than 40 hours weekly shall be added and such sums shall be divided by 40 to produce full-time position equivalents, and each full-time position equivalent shall also be considered a full-time employee for purposes of this article. Fractional equivalents shall be rounded down to the nearest whole. 
(3)  Location or office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. The renter's or lessee's location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing the real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. 
(4)  Number of employees means: 
a.  For an occupation, profession, trade, business or calling operating and having a location within the city during the calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the tax is being levied, the number of full-time employees (as defined herein) employed on August 31st during the calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the tax is being levied. For an occupation, profession, trade, business or calling that has no business location in the city on August 31st during the calendar year prior to the year in which the tax is being levied, such occupation, profession, business or calling shall fall under subsection 18-2(5)b. hereof; 
b.  For an occupation, profession, trade, business or calling not operating and having a business location within the city during the calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the tax is being levied, the number of full-time employees (as defined herein) employed during the first three months of operation at a location within the city. 
(5)  Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business and enacted by a local government as a revenue-raising ordinance or resolution. 
(6)  Occupation tax certificate means a document issued by the City of Sylvania acknowledging payment of the occupation tax. 
(7)  Person shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations which utilize 75 percent of their proceeds for charitable purposes. 
(8)  Practitioners of professions and occupations are those individuals listed in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18), but does not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business if such business pays an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 404, §§ I, II, 9-4-01) 
Sec. 18-47. - Occupation tax levied; restrictions. 
(a)  Generally. An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city and/or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the following criteria: The number of employees of the business or practitioner at each business location within the city. 
(b)  Occupation tax schedule; number of employees. The tax rate determined by number of employees for each business, trade, profession, or occupation is as follows: 

 
(c)  Restrictions. 
(1)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. 
(2)  No occupation tax shall be required from those real estate brokers, real estate agents, or real estate companies whose offices are located outside the jurisdiction and who sell property inside the jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 387, 1-5-99) 
Sec. 18-48. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in Georgia. 
Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-49. - Registration and occupation tax certificate. 
Each business shall provide information on a registration form provided by the city identifying the line or lines of business that the business conducts, the number of locations of the business, and the number of employees at each location. No business shall conduct any line of business without having that line of business, the number of locations of the business, and the number of employees at each location registered with the city clerk, and such information being noted by the city clerk on the registration form. The registration form shall be signed under penalties of perjury, and the registration form shall so indicate that it is being signed under penalties of perjury. Unless such business would be in violation of any state, federal, or local law, the city clerk shall issue an occupation tax certificate, which shall be displayed by the business in a conspicuous location. The issuance by the city clerk of an occupation tax certificate shall not be determinative for any purpose that such business is in compliance with federal, state and local law, and such registration is subject to suspension and revocation as provided for elsewhere in this article. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 426, § 1, 1-4-05) 
Sec. 18-50. - The number of businesses considered to be operating in Sylvania. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-51. - Professionals as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c), paragraphs 1 through 18. 
Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on number of employees. 
(2)  A fee of $200.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service. 
(3)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be made by January 10 of each year. If no such election is made, the occupation tax shall be based on number of employees. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-52. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-53. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 to 48-13-28. All other applicable businesses and occupations may be taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-54. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. 
(a)  Each such occupation tax shall be for the calendar year 1996 and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. Such registration and occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by April 1 of each year, be subject to a ten percent penalty for delinquency. On any new profession, trade, business or calling begun in the city in 1996 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration and tax shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business. Such new business shall estimate the number of full-time employees to be used in its business at its city location during its first three months of operation, and the occupation tax shall be paid on that basis prior to the commencement of business. The new business shall file an additional registration within 30 calendar days of its initial three months of operation with the city clerk indicating the actual number of full-time employees during its first three months of operation. At that time, the correct tax shall be calculated, and any additional tax or refund shall be due. Provided, however, for any new profession, trade, business or calling which commences business on or after July 1 in any year, the occupation tax due for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. 
(b)  In the event of a delinquency in payment of the occupation tax at the times provided for herein, a penalty of ten percent of the amount of tax owing shall be assessed by the city clerk. Such occupation tax and penalties shall be collected in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-55. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. 
No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from such registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 75 percent or more of the entire proceeds from such business are devoted to such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-56. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the Secretary of State pursuant to O.C.G.A. Title 43 shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the occupation tax certificate may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-57. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of an occupation tax certificate, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-58. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. 
All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this article shall be required to file the necessary registration and to obtain an occupation tax certificate from the city clerk as described in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to file a registration and obtain an occupation tax certificate. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise file a registration and obtain an occupation tax certificate as herein provided before commencing business; and any person transacting, or offering to transact in the city, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession, or occupation that are subject to this article without first having filed a registration and obtaining an occupation tax certificate, shall be subject to penalties provided for herein. The penalty for perjury on an occupation tax registration form shall be the same as for persons who fail to file a registration and obtain an occupation tax certificate. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 426, § 2, 1-4-05) 
Sec. 18-59. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. 
(a)  Each such occupation tax certificate shall be for the calendar year in which the occupation tax certificate was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. There is hereby imposed a penalty upon each business which fails to apply for and obtain an appropriate occupation tax certificate and pay all tax and fees as provided herein before April 1 of each year, and on April 1 each year hereafter. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall obtain the occupation tax certificate required before commencing such business. Any person transacting or offering to transact in the city any business, trade, profession, or occupation without first having obtained such occupation tax certificate shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 18-60. Such penalties shall be in addition to all other penalties herein provided; and may be collected by the remedies herein provided for collection of the occupation tax, and shall have the same lien and priority as the occupation tax to which the penalty is applied. 
(b)  The occupation tax certificate herein provided for shall be issued by the city clerk, and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain an occupation tax certificate shall, after such occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any of the kind of business, trade, profession, or occupation without having first obtained such occupation tax certificate, such offender shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 404, § III, 9-4-01) 
Sec. 18-60. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 404, § IV, adopted September 4, 2001, repealed § 18-60 in its entirety, which pertained to penalty of article violation and derived from Ord. No. 343, adopted November 21, 1995. 
Sec. 18-61. - Chief of police; subpoena and arrest powers. 
The chief of police and its duly designated officer and inspectors or its successors shall be classified as deputy marshal/business inspectors with full subpoena powers in conjunction with any violation pertaining to the business tax ordinance for 1996 and succeeding years. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 404, § V, 9-4-01) 
Sec. 18-62. - Businesses not covered by this article. 
The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. Title 46, Chapter 3. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8, et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls.) 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-63. - Payment of occupation tax by newly established businesses. 
On any new profession, trade, business or calling begun in the city in 1996 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration and tax shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business. Such new business shall estimate the number of full-time employees on the registration form to be used in its business at its city location during its first three months of operation, and the occupation tax shall be paid on that basis prior to the commencement of business. The new business shall file an additional registration form within 30 calendar days of the end of its initial three months of operation with the city clerk indicating the actual average number of full-time employees during its first three months of operation. At that time, the correct tax shall be calculated, and any additional tax or refund shall be due. Provided, however, for any new profession, trade, business or calling which commences business on or after July 1 in any year, the occupation tax due for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-64. - Inspections. 
The city clerk, through its officers, agents, employees or representatives, may inspect the books and records of any business subject to the occupation tax, as well as the business premises of any such business, to insure compliance with this article. Failure to submit to an inspection during regular business hours, or to provide access to the books and records of the business within 48 hours of being requested, shall be grounds for revocation or suspension of the occupation tax certificate. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the city clerk at that officer's discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of 125 percent of the prime interest rate times the amount deficient will be assessed for the period delinquent. For purposes of this section, the prime interest rate shall be that which is published by The Wall Street Journal on the first business day of the year in which the underreported tax is due. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-65. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax. 
In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the city clerk, upon any tax or installment of such tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of the tax against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for the tax, which execution shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for the tax, all as provided by law. The lien of such occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the chief of police of the city upon the property of defendant located in the jurisdiction, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of the execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by ordinances and charter of the city and the laws of the state, and the defendant in the execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the city clerk against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him or her as though he or she had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-66. - Suspension; revocation. 
(a)  All occupation tax certificates issued by the city clerk under the provisions of this article shall be subject to suspension by the mayor and suspension or revocation by the mayor and council upon the following terms and in the following manner: Upon information being furnished by any person that the holder of any occupation tax certificate issued under the provisions of this article has, in connection with the business, trade, profession or vocation for which this occupation tax certificate was issued, committed acts or is guilty of conduct contrary to the laws of the United States, the state, the city or is guilty of conduct contrary to the public health, morals, peace or welfare of the citizens of the city, it shall be the duty of the mayor to issue or cause to be issued a written notice, directed to the holder of the license, requiring the license holder to appear before the mayor and council and show cause why the license should not be suspended or revoked. The notice shall disclose the charges against the holder of the certificate and shall state the time, date and place of hearing, which hearing shall not be held less than five days nor more than 15 days from the date of receipt of the notice by the certificate holder. If, upon final hearing, the mayor and council shall, in accordance with the opinion they entertain as to the evidence and testimony submitted, believe that the certificate holder is guilty of the charges made, it shall be their duty to suspend or revoke the certificate of the person to whom it was issued or by whom it was held. 
(b)  The mayor may, if he shall deem it necessary for the protection or welfare of the people of the city, suspend the occupation tax certificate of any person against whom charges have been made, pending final hearing on the issue of whether or not the occupation tax certificate of this person should be further suspended or revoked. Prior to any such suspension, the mayor shall hold an informal hearing with the holder of the occupation tax certificate to hear such holder's response to the charges and the proposed suspension. The mayor shall then make the decision regarding suspension pending final hearing. In the event of either suspension or revocation, such person shall immediately cease to conduct the business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, for which the occupation tax certificate was issued, or suffer the penalties set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-67. - Amendment, repeal of provision. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the jurisdiction of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-68. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-69. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk and chief of police to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the court. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-70. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by governing body. 
This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the council. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-71. - Public hearing requirements. 
(a)  After April 11, 1995, the council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution regarding the occupation tax. 
(b)  In any year when revenue from the occupation taxes is greater than revenue from occupation taxes for the preceding year for the city, then council shall hold one or more public hearings as a part of the process of determining how to use the additional revenue. Such hearing may be included in the public hearing portion of the city budget process. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-72. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. 
The council may by subsequent ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the governing authority, or in any such subsequent resolution or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-73. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-74. - Severability. 
If any section, provision, or clause of any part of this article shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this article as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such individuality shall not be construed to affect the portions of this article not so held to be invalid, or the application of this article to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this article would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-75. - Saving provision. 
Chapter 6 of this Code, sections 6-1 through 6-36, inclusive, as may be amended from time to time, shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-76. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article, and not preserved hereby, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 343, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 18-77. - Civil penalties. 
In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, any court of competent jurisdiction for the enforcement of ordinances of the city may impose a civil fine for failure to pay the occupation tax in an amount not to exceed $500.00, and said civil fine may be enforced by the contempt power of the court. 
(Ord. No. 404, § VI, 9-4-01) 
Secs. 18-78—18-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEALERS IN PRECIOUS METALS, ANTIQUES, AND OBJECTS D'ART[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Duties of purchasers of gold bullion, gold dust, etc., O.C.G.A. § 12-4-120 et seq.; junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1 et seq.; dealers in precious metals and gems, O.C.G.A. § 43-37-1 et seq.; dealers in used watches, O.C.G.A. § 43-49-1 et seq.; jeweler's lien for repairs, O.C.G.A. § 44-14-430 et seq. 

Sec. 18-81. - Compliance required. 
Any person who wishes to conduct a business within the corporate limits of the city for purposes of purchasing from individual citizens at large gold, silver, other precious metals, antiques, similar artifacts or objects d'art, shall comply with the requirements set out in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1014) 
Sec. 18-82. - Regular place of business. 
A person conducting a business under this article shall have a regular office or place of business, which shall be a permanent structure located within the corporate limits of the city, and either owned or leased by such person as shall conduct the business. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1014(A)) 
Sec. 18-83. - Records; inspection; copies furnished to chief of police. 
(a)  A person conducting a business under this article shall maintain complete records of each purchase made, to include the name of the seller; a description of the item or items purchased; describing same in detail; the date and time of the sale; and the price paid therefor. 
(b)  Such records shall be available for inspection by the city manager, city clerk, and chief of police of the city or their designated agents, at all times. 
(c)  Copies in quadruplicate of the information for the preceding seven calendar days shall be furnished to the chief of police on or before 4:00 p.m. of every Friday, when such person shall have had any transaction within the corporate limits during the preceding seven days. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1014(B)—(D)) 
Sec. 18-84. - Waiting period after purchase. 
Any item so purchased under this article must be retained in the same size, shape, configuration and design as it is in when purchased for a period of ten days after such purchase. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1014(E)) 
Sec. 18-85. - Violations; penalty. 
Any violation of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 upon conviction. In addition, any complaint of violation shall be immediately investigated by the police department and should such investigation disclose probable cause for citation for violation of this article then this shall cause the immediate suspension of any business license issued hereunder and termination of such license upon conviction of such offense. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1014(F)) 
Secs. 18-86—18-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS' LICENSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Electrical contractors, plumbers, conditioned air contractors, low-voltage contractors, and utility contractors, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-1 et seq. 

Sec. 18-106. - Application. 
Any person doing any type of electrical work within the city must have a current electrical license issued by the city. Such electrical license shall be issued upon such individual presenting to the city clerk a valid license issued under the Georgia Electrical Contractors Act, which is sometimes also referred to as a state electrical card, together with such additional information as shall be reasonably required to establish that the person tendering such card is the same person whose name appears thereon. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1081) 
Sec. 18-107. - Renewal. 
Any person who, on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives, already has a license to do electrical work under any provision of the charter and Code of the city as same existed prior to the enactment of this article, shall be entitled to the issuance of a new license hereunder without the necessity of going through the procedure outlined in the Georgia Electrical Contractors Act. Such license, however, shall expire annually. Upon such annual expiration the license shall be renewed by application to the city clerk within 30 days of the expiration date, which application shall state that the applicant has held a city electrical license for the preceding year and shall be accompanied by such fee as shall be set from time to time by the mayor and council. Should such license not be renewed within 30 days of the annual expiration thereof, the holder of such expired license may obtain a new license only upon complying with the requirements of the Georgia Electrical Contractors Act, as well as paying whatever fee shall be set by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1082) 
Sec. 18-108. - Fee. 
The mayor and council shall from time to time establish the fee for the granting of a city electrical license. The amount of such fee shall be readily available to the public at the offices of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1083) 
Sec. 18-109. - Installation and disconnection of electric load management devices. 
(a)  Any electrical contractor licensed under this article to do business in the city: 
(1)  Shall not disconnect a load management device which is installed, connected and operating without giving prior notice to the city manager. 
(2)  Shall notify the city manager immediately upon discovering a load management device which is inoperative or disconnected. 
(3)  Shall notify the city manager of all new central air conditioning installations which are to be made at locations served with electrical power by the city, such notification to be prior to the installation so that the city manager can advise the property owner of the merits and benefits of installing a load management device. 
(b)  Failure to abide by the terms of this section may result in the suspension of a license granted under this article and shall also be considered a violation of this Code punishable as provided in section 1-12 upon conviction. 
(Ord. No. 237, 12-6-83) 
Secs. 18-110—18-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDDLERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Disabled veterans and blind persons engaging in peddling, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1; Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; Transient Merchants Act of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. 

Sec. 18-131. - Definition. 
For purposes of this article, the term "peddler" shall be defined as any person or entity which sells goods, wares or merchandise from a location which is not owned or rented by such person or entity or from a vehicle or structure which is not permanently affixed to real estate. 
(Ord. No. 264, § I, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 18-132. - Restrictions. 
No peddler may sell or display his goods, wares or merchandise on any street or sidewalk within the municipal boundaries of the city. Peddlers may sell and display their goods, wares or merchandise only upon private property with the permission of the property owner upon compliance with the other provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 264, § II, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 18-133. - Licensing requirements. 
All peddlers shall be granted a business license by the city upon the payment of a license fee of $300.00 together with the applicant's providing written proof satisfactory to the city clerk that such applicant has permission from a private property owner to display and sell his goods, wares or merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 264, § III, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 18-134. - Exceptions. 
None of the provisions of this article shall extend to persons or entities selling agricultural products grown in the county. 
(Ord. No. 264, § IV, 6-17-86) 
Secs. 18-135—18-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - YARD SALES 

Sec. 18-156. - Definition. 
A "yard sale" is defined as the sale or trading of used clothing, furniture, household items, food, dishes, antiques or similar goods or merchandise on a lot utilized primarily for residential purposes. The term "yard sale" shall include garage sales, carport sales and similar types of sales or events. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 1, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-157. - Location. 
Yard sales may be held on a lot or parcel of land upon which there is situated a house, apartment or other structure which is utilized primarily for residential purposes. Yard sales are prohibited upon vacant lots and upon lots upon which there is situated a structure that is utilized primarily for any use other than residential purposes. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 2, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-158. - Permit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a yard sale in the city without a permit. Any person who occupies a house, apartment or other structure in the city as his primary residence shall, upon request, be issued a permit by the city clerk or his designated representative to conduct a yard sale at the location of such house, apartment or residential structure. There shall be no fee charged for such permit. The permit shall contain the date of the yard sale, the duration of the permit, the address of the yard sale and the name or names of the permittees. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 3, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-159. - Additional permitted persons. 
The person or persons issued a permit under section 18-158 may designate additional permittees who are not occupants of the structure on the permitted premises as their primary residence. Such persons so designated shall be added as additional permittees on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 4, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-160. - Posting of permit. 
The holder or holders of a yard sale permit shall cause the permit to be conspicuously posted on the permitted premises at all times during which the yard sale is being conducted. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 5, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-161. - Restriction on goods sold. 
Only the sale or trading of used clothing, furniture, household items, food, dishes, antiques or similar goods or merchandise that are actually owned by the permittee or permittees shall be allowed at the permitted yard sale location. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 6, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-162. - Number permitted. 
(a)  Per year. No person shall be permitted to conduct or participate in more than four yard sales per year. 
(b)  Per location. No particular location shall be permitted for more than four yard sales per year. 
(c)  Number of days. Any given yard sale shall not continue for a period exceeding two consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 7, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-163. - Time, days of sale. 
No yard sale shall be conducted on Sunday, and shall be allowed only between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 8, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-164. - Charitable and religious organizations. 
No charitable or religious organization shall conduct a yard sale without a permit. Organizations existing for charitable or religious purposes, and only those which have a regularly functioning organizational structure and regularly functioning board of directors, shall be issued a permit to conduct a yard sale only upon private property, and not upon the city streets or sidewalks. Such organizations shall not be restricted to residential property, but shall conduct such yard sale upon its own property, or upon private property with the written permission of the owner or lessee of such private property. Yard sales by charitable or religious organizations shall otherwise be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 9, 2-5-91) 
Sec. 18-165. - Penalty. 
Any person violating this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-12 upon conviction. 
(Ord. No. 308, § 10, 2-5-91) 
Secs. 18-166—18-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BILLIARD ROOMS[7] 

Footnotes:
