Chapter 34 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Fire department, § 3.102; fire limits, § 8.103. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; cable communications, ch. 22; environment, ch. 30; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; telecommunications towers and antennae, ch. 68; traffic and vehicles, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 74. 
State Law reference— Authority to provide police and fire protection, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(1); statewide application of Standard Fire Prevention Code, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; The Uniform Act for the Application of Building and Fire Related Codes to Existing Buildings, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-200; providing of fire escapes by building owners, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; obstruction or hindering of firefighters, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24.1; regulation of fire and other hazards to persons and property generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq.; local fire departments generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-2 et seq.; authority to enact ordinances or fire and life safety codes, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-4; firefighter standards and training, O.C.G.A. § 25-4-2 et seq.; mutual aid resource pacts, O.C.G.A. § 25-6-1; Georgia Fire Academy Act, O.C.G.A. § 25-7-1 et seq.; regulation of fireworks, O.C.G.A. § 25-10-1 et seq.; electronic security systems installed and serviced by counties or municipal corporations, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-12. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Fire limits established. 
The fire limits of the city shall be the city limits. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1016) 
Sec. 34-2. - Authority of chief. 
The chief of the fire department is hereby authorized to discipline and suspend members of the fire department. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2001) 
Sec. 34-3. - Fire hydrants—Obstructing. 
(a)  No person shall obstruct with building material, equipment or in any manner whatsoever any fire hydrant which would obstruct approaches thereto by any member of the fire department. 
(b)  No person shall put any posts or installation of any nature whatsoever nearer than 18 inches to any fire hydrant without first obtaining written permission from the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2002) 
Sec. 34-4. - Same—Responsibility for inspections and repair. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department shall be responsible for any inspection and examination of all fire hydrants in the city. The inspection and examination shall be made at least every six months, and the chief shall file a report concerning the condition of the fire hydrants with the city manager. 
(b)  If any fire hydrant is in need of immediate repair, he shall immediately notify the city manager, who shall take immediate action to have the fire hydrant repaired. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2003) 
Sec. 34-5. - Same—Unlawful acts. 
No person shall remove the cover from any fire hydrant within this city, connect fire hose thereto, or turn on or use water therefrom, except for the purpose of fighting a fire, without express authority of the city manager. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2004) 
Sec. 34-6. - Appeals. 
Whenever the city manager shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the city manager to mayor and council within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2026) 
Sec. 34-7. - Manufacture of explosives. 
The manufacture of explosives is prohibited in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2031) 
Sec. 34-8. - Trucks used for transporting inflammable materials; parking. 
(a)  All trucks used for transporting butane and propane gas, gasoline, kerosene and other similar inflammable material shall not be parked within any area extending for one-half mile from the courthouse except for the delivery of these products to consumers and dealers. 
(b)  Trucks used for transporting these materials shall not be parked in any congested or residential area within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2041) 
Sec. 34-9. - Burning permit. 
(a)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful to burn any lawn, trash, leaves, pine straw or rubbish of any kind without first obtaining a written permit signed by the fire chief of the city, or another member of the city fire department designated by the fire chief to issue written permits. 
(b)  Terms of permit. The written permit to burn shall contain the following requirements: 
(1)  Permit required: No person shall burn any lawn, trash, leaves, pine straw or rubbish of any kind without written permit signed by the fire chief of the city, or another member of the city fire department designated by the fire chief to issue written permits. 
(2)  Any fire shall be constantly attended by an able-bodied person at least 18 years of age until extinguished. Such person shall have a garden hose connected to a water supply, or other fire extinguishing equipment readily available for use. 
(3)  The fire chief or other member of the city fire department designated by the fire chief may prohibit any or all outdoor fires when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous. 
(4)  Any member of the city fire department may extinguish or cause to be extinguished any fire, including the fire for which this permit is issued, if, in his opinion, the fire is endangering life or property, or is becoming a nuisance to other persons. 
(c)  Other requirements. 
(1)  The person applying for the permit shall designate the kinds of materials to be burned, and only those materials shall be burned. Under no circumstances shall explosive, noxious or toxic materials be burned. 
(2)  The person applying for the permit shall designate the location of the burning, and no burning shall be permitted outside of the location so designated. 
(3)  The person applying for the permit shall provide a phone number where such person can be reached or contacted before and during the burning. 
(4)  The permit shall be valid only for the date for which it is issued. 
(5)  The permit shall be signed by the applicant and the fire chief or another member of the city fire department designated by the fire chief. 
(d)  Penalty. Any violation of any provisions of this section or of the permit to burn issued hereunder shall be punishable for the first offense by a fine not exceeding $50.00, and for subsequent offenses, by a fine not exceeding $500.00 and imprisonment not exceeding six months. 
(Ord. No. 336, §§ 3—6, 7-19-94) 
Secs. 34-10—34-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SMOKE DETECTORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Smoke detectors required in new dwellings and dwelling units; exceptions, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-40. 

Sec. 34-36. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
New dwelling means all new single occupancy and multiple occupancy residential dwellings (including mobile homes) which are constructed, erected or installed subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives. The term "new dwelling" as applied to multiple occupancy residential dwellings shall mean each separate apartment or other subpart of the building which is intended for occupancy by one family or group. 
Smoke detector means a device used for the purpose of detecting heat or smoke, and which is approved by the Underwriters Laboratory, Inc., or other comparable testing firm. 
(Ord. No. 252, § I, 6-18-85) 
Sec. 34-37. - Installation required for new dwellings. 
All new dwellings shall have a smoke detector installed on each story of the dwelling for each 1,500 square feet of floor space on each story. 
(Ord. No. 252, § II, 6-18-85) 
Sec. 34-38. - Time of installation. 
Smoke detectors as required by section 34-37 hereof shall be installed and operational prior to the occupancy of a new dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 252, § III, 6-18-85) 
Sec. 34-39. - Maintenance. 
It shall be the responsibility of the occupant of each new dwelling to install and maintain operational all smoke detectors required in a new dwelling at all times. 
(Ord. No. 252, § IV, 6-18-85) 
Sec. 34-40. - Enforcement. 
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 upon conviction. 
(Ord. No. 252, § V, 6-18-85) 
Secs. 34-41—34-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE LANES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; traffic and vehicles, ch. 70. 

Sec. 34-61. - Requirements. 
All buildings, other than single family residences, which are set back more than 150 feet from a public road, or which exceed 30 feet in height and are set back over 50 feet from the right-of-way of a public road shall have designated fire lanes with appropriate markings. Any other buildings within the city may have designated fire lanes with appropriate markings. The fire lane so designated shall be at least 12 feet in width, beginning at least ten feet, but not more than 20 feet, from the main building (excluding covered or uncovered sidewalk area), and extending outward from such point 12 feet. The length of the fire lane shall be at least 30 feet, and on buildings which are 230 feet in length or greater, fire lanes shall be spaced no greater than 170 feet apart, and shall be located to give access to the entire building for fire apparatus. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 1, 1-18-94) 
Sec. 34-62. - Markings. 
Fire lanes shall be marked with bright yellow, orange or red paint with either diagonal lines running the entire length and width of such lane or the words "fire lane" running the entire length and width of such fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 2, 1-18-94) 
Sec. 34-63. - Maintenance. 
In the event that any fire lane as designated in section 34-61 above is situated on private property (i.e., property that has not been dedicated to or which is not otherwise owned by the city, county, or the state), it shall be the responsibility of the owner of the premises to provide and maintain the fire lane with clear appropriate markings as set forth in section 34-62 above. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 3, 1-18-94) 
Sec. 34-64. - Variances. 
(a)  In the event this article works a hardship upon any person or entity, such person or entity may make written application to the fire chief for a variance. The fire chief shall then present the application for variance to the zoning board of adjustment, which board shall have the authority and power to grant a variance to this article provided that the board determines that the building or buildings in question have been provided, or shall be provided within a specified time as set by the board, adequate access to fire apparatus. The board shall give strong consideration to the recommendation of the fire chief. 
(b)  A hearing before the zoning board of adjustment shall be held within 30 days of the filing of the application with the fire chief. All hearings before the board shall be informal, and rules of evidence shall not apply. The decision of the board shall be in writing, and shall be rendered within ten days of the hearing. The applicant shall be notified of the hearing date, and shall have the right to be present. Any appeal from the decision of the board shall be by certiorari to the county superior court. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 4, 1-18-94) 
Sec. 34-65. - Violations. 
(a)  Parking in fire lane. It is hereby unlawful to park or leave unattended any car, truck, motorcycle or other vehicle in any portion of a fire lane, or to otherwise obstruct a fire lane with any object. Anyone violating this subsection shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $25.00; notice of a violation and collection of fine shall be in the same manner as that for the parking violations. 
(b)  Failure to maintain. Any owner of private property upon which there is situated a fire lane who fails to properly maintain such fire lane with clear and appropriate markings as set forth in sections 34-62 and 34-63 above, shall be in violation of this article. Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this subsection shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $250.00. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 5, 1-18-94) 
Secs. 34-66—34-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIFE SAFETY CODE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 417, §§ I—IV, adopted August 5, 2003, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as article IV, §§ 34-76—34-79 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 34-76. - Adoption of Life Safety Code. 
The 2000 edition of the Code For Safety To Life From Fire In Buildings and Structures (a/k/a The Life Safety Code), as the same shall be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference, exempting one and two family residential dwellings except when any such dwelling is used either in conjunction with or solely for the following uses: 
(1)  Child day care; 
(2)  The provision of health care services; or 
(3)  Assisted care for the elderly or disabled. 
(Ord. No. 417, § I, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 34-77. - Enforcement. 
The Life Safety Code shall be enforced by the fire chief for the city or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 417, § II, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 34-78. - Adoption by reference of Uniform Act for the Application of Building and Fire Related Codes to existing buildings. 
The Uniform Act for the Application of Building and Fire Related Codes to existing buildings set forth at O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-200 et seq. is hereby incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 417, § III, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 34-79. - Building and code enforcement authorities relieved from liability. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to constitute a waiver of the sovereign immunity of the city or any officer or employee thereof in carrying out the provisions of this article. Further, no action shall be maintained against the city or any duly authorized elected or appointed officer or duly authorized employee thereof, for damages sustained as a result of any fire or hazard covered by this article by reason of inspection or other action taken or not taken pursuant to this article. Nothing in article shall be construed to relieve any property owner or lessee or person in charge thereof from any legal duty, obligation, or liability incident to the ownership, maintenance, or use of such property. 
(Ord. No. 417, § IV, 8-5-03) 
Chapter 38 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; offenses, ch. 50; solid waste, ch. 58; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 74. 
State Law reference— Power of county board of health to adopt and enforce rules and regulations, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-4(4); rules and regulations of local application, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-6; promulgation of rules, regulations and standards by department of human resources and county boards of health, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-373. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Public restrooms at laundromats. 
(a)  All businesses commonly known as laundromats shall furnish access to a sanitary toilet facility for use by the patrons of such laundromat at all hours that the business is open. 
(b)  Laundromats as referred to herein shall be defined as a business offering clothes washing or drying machines for use by the public generally for a fee. 
(Code 1976, § 10-4004) 
Secs. 38-2—38-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE WELLS AND WATER SYSTEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Water Well Standards Act of 1985, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-120. 

Sec. 38-26. - Prohibited generally. 
The city's public water system provides a safe and healthy source of potable water for its citizens. It is in the best interest of the health, safety and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city that the city's public water system be used by all inhabitants for purposes of potable water, to the greatest extent possible. There exists within the city, however, three private wells being used as a source of potable water, which private wells have been utilized by the present owners and predecessors in title for many years without any apparent adverse health or safety problems. In balancing the property rights of the owners of these three private wells against any adverse health and safety considerations of such owners and other inhabitants of the city, it is the belief of the mayor and council that these three private wells should be grandfathered for purposes of this article, provided that such owners prevent any cross-connection with and contamination of the city's public water system. Otherwise, private wells utilized as a source of potable water shall be prohibited within the city. 
(Ord. No. 289, art. I, 5-17-88) 
Sec. 38-27. - Permit to drill well for purposes other than potable water. 
The city's public water system provides potable water. Private wells may not be established for potable water purposes, but may be established for other specific purposes. The following guidelines shall govern the application for an approval of a permit to drill a private well: 
(1)  A building permit to drill a private well shall be applied for, and such permit shall issue upon applicant's meeting all applicable city building, electrical and plumbing codes, and upon approval by the building inspector and payment of a fee of $1.50 per $1,000.00 of project cost, with a $2.00 minimum fee. 
(2)  A private well shall meet all location requirements of the zoning ordinances of the city. 
(3)  Well construction shall comply with state department of human resources recommendations. 
(4)  No interconnection between any private water supply and the city system shall be allowed. 
(5)  The water system fed by the private well shall not be connected to the city's system at any time. The principal user of the property shall continue to use the city's water system as its only source of potable water. The property owner is directly responsible for the prevention of any crossover-connection. 
(Ord. No. 289, art. II, 5-17-88) 
Sec. 38-28. - Discharge into city sewerage system. 
Water or wastewater from a private well system may not be discharged into the city's sanitary sewerage system. 
(Ord. No. 289, art. III, 5-17-88) 
Sec. 38-29. - Grandfathering of certain private wells. 
(a)  Private wells which are being used as a source of potable water at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives may continue to be utilized as a source of potable water provided that the owners thereof comply with the remaining provisions of this article. Such wells are located at the following property addresses: 
(1)  510 North Main Street, Sylvania, Georgia 30467. 
(2)  501 North Main Street, Sylvania, Georgia 30467. 
(3)  311 Cork Pond Road, Sylvania, Georgia 30467. 
(b)  The owners of the private wells set forth in subsection (a) hereof shall ensure that there is no interconnection between the private water supply and the city's public water system, and the means of preventing such interconnection shall be first approved by the city building inspector, and shall be subject to inspection under section 38-30. 
(c)  The owners of private wells set forth in subsection (a) hereof may discharge water or wastewater from the private well system into the city's sanitary sewerage system provided that such owners pay the maximum sewer charge each month to the city. 
(d)  The owners of private wells set forth in subsection (a) hereof shall not levy any charge upon any person or entity for the use of any such well. 
(Ord. No. 289, art. IV, 5-17-88) 
Sec. 38-30. - Inspection. 
Each private well system shall be made available for immediate inspection by the city at any time and without prior notice. An annual inspection shall be made by the city building official. 
(Ord. No. 289, art. V, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 391, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 38-31. - Penalty. 
Any person violating this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 upon conviction. 
(Ord. No. 289, art. VI, 5-17-88) 
Secs. 38-32—38-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BODY ART STUDIOS AND ARTISTS 

Sec. 38-50. - Authority. 
The legal authority for this rule is O.C.G.A. § 16-5-71 and chapter 31-40 (O.C.G.A. §§ 16-5-71, 31-40-1, 31-40-2, 31-40-3, 31-40-4, 31-40-5, 31-40-6, 31-40-7, 31-40-8, 31-40-9, and chapter 31-5). 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-51. - Purpose. 
The purpose of these rules and regulations is to establish reasonable standards for individuals performing tattoo and body piercing procedures and for the facilities from which the procedures are provided. Such standards should insure the health and safety of all individuals performing and receiving these services. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-52. - Exemptions. 
These regulations do not apply to a physician or osteopath licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, chapter 34, or a technician acting under the direct supervision of such licensed physician or osteopath. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-53. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise defined by specific sections as used in these rules and regulations the term: 
Antibacterial solution means any solution used to retard the growth of bacteria approved for application to human skin and includes all products labeled accordingly. 
Body art studio means a permanent building or structure on a permanent foundation, holding a valid city or county business license and permit from the county board of health, wherein a tattoo/body piercing artist performs tattooing or body piercing. This shall not include tattoo removal. 
Body piercing means the creation of an opening in an individual's body other than the individual's ear, to insert jewelry or other decoration. 
Body piercing artist means any person who performs body piercing. 
County means the local county board of health or its duly authorized representatives, and is sometimes referred to herein as the local board of health, the county board of health, the local county board of health, or the local health department. 
Currently licensed health care professional means and includes physicians, registered nurses (RN), licensed practical nurses (LPN), and licensed emergency medical technicians. 
Department means the state department of human resources. 
Governing body means the partnership, the corporation, the association, or the person or group of persons who maintain and control the tattoo/body piercing studio and who are legally responsible for the operation of the studio. 
OSHA means Occupational Safety and Health Association. 
Permit means the authorization granted by the county to the governing body to operate a tattoo/body piercing studio. 
Plan of correction means a plan for correcting deficiencies in meeting rules and regulations of the department of human resources and/or the local county board of health. 
Sanitary means clean and free of agents of infection or disease. 
Sanitized means effective antibacterial treatment by a process that provides sufficient concentration of chemicals for enough time to reduce the bacteria count including pathogens to a safe level on equipment. 
Sterilization means holding an instrument in an autoclave for required length of time at 15 to 30 pounds pressure at a temperature of 249.8 degrees Fahrenheit or 121 degrees Celsius. 
Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking in, piercing, or implanting indelible pigments or dyes under the skin. 
Tattoo artist means any person who performs tattooing. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-54. - Governing body. 
(a)  The governing body shall be responsible for compliance with the requirements in O.C.G.A. chapter 31-40, with applicable administrative rules and regulations of the local county board of health, including, but not limited to, all applicable statutes, rules and regulations regarding disclosure of ownership. 
(b)  The governing body shall certify in its application the name(s) and exact duties of employees/artists who have been designated as being responsible for carrying out the rules and policies adopted by the governing body. The following information shall be included: social security number, job, gender, home address, home/work phone numbers, ID photos of all operators/technicians. 
(c)  Prior to being granted a permit, each body art studio shall develop a written statement of policies and procedures outlining the responsibilities of management. 
(d)  No one under the age of 18 shall be tattooed. The tattooing of a minor is prohibited in the State of Georgia. No one under the age of 18 shall be pierced without the presence and written permission of their legal guardian. No one under the age of 14 shall be pierced. 
(e)  Tattoo/body piercing artists shall not be under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs while performing tattoo/body piercing procedures. 
(f)  Operators shall refuse services to any person, who in the opinion of the operator, is under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(g)  No animals, except for guide dogs accompanying disabled persons, shall be allowed in the tattoo/body piercing studio. 
(h)  Piercing of a minor. For any piercing of a minor, a parent or legal guardian must be present to sign a consent form for each piercing procedure. It is a violation of the rules and regulations for anyone performing body piercing on an individual under age 18 without the consent of the individual's parent or guardian. Consent must specify the part of the body to be pierced. Required consent is the written and physical presence of the individual's parent or guardian and the provision of evidence stating their parental or guardian status. Proof-positive, state-issued photo identification is required from the legal guardian, and a bona fide form of identification from the minor. In the event the parent has a different last name and/or address from the child, court documentation is needed to prove the relationship, i.e., divorce papers, or a remarriage certificate. Copies of all identification for legal guardian will need to be retained in client's file. Under no circumstances is it acceptable or appropriate for an artist to perform piercing on the nipples or genitals of an individual under 18 years of age. Violation of the 'piercing of minor' procedures may result in the revocation of artist's permit, revocation of studio permit, and/or further enforcement action deemed appropriate by the health authority. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-55. - Minimum floor plan requirements. 
(a)  The body art studio shall be constructed, arranged, and maintained as to provide adequately for the health and safety of its customers. 
(b)  The studio shall be constructed in a manner to allow the customer receiving the tattoo/body piercing adequate privacy from observers. The work area shall be separate from the waiting area. 
(c)  Body art studios must have adequate ventilation. 
(d)  Walls and ceilings must be painted or covered in a manner which would allow for easy and effective cleaning. Paint or covering must be light in color. 
(e)  Floors of the work area must not be carpeted. Surfaces shall be of a nonabsorbent material that would allow for effective cleaning by conventional methods. 
(f)  A clean and sanitary toilet and hand washing facility shall be made accessible to customers; however, it shall be separate from the work area. 
(g)  The work area shall be equipped with at least one sink and basin providing hot and cold running water for the use of the artists for washing their hands and preparing customers for tattooing/piercing. This area shall be provided with soap, an antibacterial solution, single use towels or air blower, and individual hand brushes for each artist. 
(h)  The facility shall be equipped with at least one utility sink, providing hot and cold running water for use in cleaning reusable receptacles and the facility. 
(i)  The work area shall be provided with adequate lighting. 
(j)  The work area shall not be used as a corridor for access to other rooms. 
(k)  The body art studio shall be constructed in a manner to allow the customer receiving the procedure adequate privacy from observers; thus the procedure room shall be separated by a fixed and solid door, wall, or partition extending from floor to ceiling from any other area including the waiting area. 
(l)  The body art studio shall not be allowed to occur in automobiles, mobile, transitory or other non-fixed facilities. Such non-fixed facilities include, but are not limited to, mobile homes, tents, recreational vehicles, and trailers. 
(m)  Body art studios shall not be allowed in facilities used for human habitation, any food service establishment, hair salon, nail salon, retail sales area, hotel room or similar areas. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-56. - Furnishings and fixtures. 
(a)  Furnishings of the body art studio shall be maintained in good condition, intact, and functional. Furnishings should be made of or covered in a material that is easily cleanable and nonabsorbent. The studio shall be kept clean, neat, and free of litter and rubbish. 
(b)  Cabinets for the storage of instruments, dyes, pigments, single use articles, carbon, and stencils shall be provided for each tattoo artist and shall be maintained in a sanitary manner which protects them from contamination. 
(c)  Work tables and chairs shall be provided for each tattoo/body piercing artist. 
(1)  Surfaces of all work tables and chairs shall be constructed of material which is smooth, nonabsorbent, corrosive resistant, and easily sanitized. 
(2)  Work tables and chairs shall be sanitized with a bactericidal solution after each application. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-57. - Supplies. 
(a)  Bulk single use articles shall be commercially packaged and handled to protect them from contamination. These articles shall be stored in an area separate from the toilet facilities. 
(b)  All materials applied to the human skin shall be from single use containers and shall be disposed of after each use. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-58. - Dyes and pigments. 
(a)  All dyes and pigments used in tattooing shall be from professional suppliers specifically providing dyes and/or pigments for the tattooing of human skin. 
(b)  In preparing dyes or pigments to be used by a tattoo artist, only nontoxic sterile materials shall be used. Single-use or individual portions of dyes or pigments in clean, sterilized individual containers or single-use containers shall be used for each patron. 
(c)  After tattooing, the remaining unused dye or pigment in the single-use or individual containers shall be discarded along with the container. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-59. - Regarding piercers jewelry. 
(a)  Client and piercer should have appropriate size and quality jewelry chosen before the procedure begins. 
(b)  Jewelry used in piercing shall consist of an approved material suitable for permanent surgical implant, such as, high quality surgical stainless steel (316LVM series), niobium, titanium, platinum or a dense low porosity plastic material such as Tygon or PTFE. Copies of the jewelry manufacturer's documentation, which verify compliance with standards, must be available for inspection on request of the local health department. Solid 14 karat, or high, white or yellow nickel-free gold may be used. Purity verification must also be available for inspection on request of the director. Appropriate jewelry has no nicks, scratches, or irregular surfaces. 
(c)  Ear studs or other jewelry designed for earlobe piercing are not appropriate jewelry for other body parts and must not be used by piercers. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-60. - Sanitation. 
(a)  Prior to the start of the tattoo/body piercing procedure the artist should inspect his/her hands for hangnails, small cuts, sores, and abrasions. If a cut, sore, or abrasion is detected, a bandage should be applied for added protection before gloving. Trim fingernails to insure that gloves are not punctured. 
(b)  All jewelry such as watches, rings, etc. should be removed prior to the start of the tattoo procedure. 
(c)  Before working on each client, the fingernails and hands of the tattoo/body piercing artist shall be thoroughly washed and scrubbed with warm water, and antibacterial soap, using an individual hand brush that is clean and in good repair. The hands should then be dried by either an air blower or by single use towels prior to beginning work on each client or when interrupted in the process. 
(d)  Single use disposable latex or approved non-latex examination gloves shall be worn during the tattooing process. Gloves shall be changed and properly disposed of each time there is an interruption in the application of the tattoo, the gloves become torn or punctured, or whenever their ability to function is compromised. 
(e)  Each artist shall wear a clean outer garment, apron or smock. These items shall be changed after each client. 
(f)  Tattoo/body piercing artists who are experiencing symptoms of diarrhea, vomiting, fever, rash, or skin infections shall refrain from tattooing/body piercing activities. 
(g)  Adequate numbers of sterilized needles and tubes must be on hand for each artist for the entire day and night operation. 
(h)  Only single-use disposable razors shall be used to shave the area to be tattooed. 
(i)  Smoking and consumption of food or drink is prohibited in body art studio. 
(j)  Universal precautions are to be followed per OSHA standards and guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-61. - Sterilization. 
(a)  An operational sterilizer (autoclave) shall be provided in each body art studio. 
(b)  Non-disposable instruments shall be kept in a separate puncture resistant container until brush scrubbed in hot water and soap, and then sterilized by autoclaving. 
(c)  The following procedures should be followed during the sterilization process: 
(1)  Prior to being placed in the autoclave all equipment shall be bagged, labeled, dated and sealed. 
(2)  Each autoclave bag may hold no more than one tube with needle and bar. 
(3)  Autoclave shall be operated according to manufacturer's instructions and shall be made available for inspection. 
(4)  Spore indicators shall be used a minimum of at least once a month and the results must be kept at location for a minimum of three years. 
(d)  If using pre-sterilized equipment, documentation must be on file from equipment manufacturer that describes the method of sterilization meeting the manufacturer's recommendations for storage and maintenance of sterility. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-62. - Tattoo preparation. 
(a)  Before placing the tattoo design on the client's skin, the artist shall treat the skin area with an antibacterial solution. 
(b)  If an acetate stencil is used by a tattoo artist for transferring the design to the skin, it shall be thoroughly cleaned and rinsed in a germicidal solution for at least 20 minutes and then dried with sterile gauze or dried in the air on a sanitized surface after each use. 
(c)  If a paper stencil is used by a tattoo artist for transferring the design to the skin, it shall be single-use and disposable. 
(d)  If the design is drawn directly onto the skin, it shall be applied with a single-use article only. 
(e)  By O.C.G.A. § 16-12-5 no tattooing within one inch of the eye socket except by a physician or a technician under the direct supervision of a physician. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-63. - Requirements for body piercers. 
Body piercers shall: 
(1)  Set up equipment in front of client. 
(2)  Open sealed autoclave bags containing sterile equipment in front of client, and discard the autoclave bag. 
(3)  Disinfect all jewelry contaminated with only airborne pathogens (not previously worn or contaminated) with a non-hazardous hard surface disinfectant approved by the EPA. All jewelry contaminated or potentially contaminated with blood-borne pathogens (previously worn by another person) should be autoclaved, stored in sterile indicator bags, sealed and dated. 
(4)  Pre-sterilize all needles used in piercing, use only on one person, at one sitting, for a single piercing, and immediately dispose of in a medical sharps container. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-64. - After tattoo/body piercing application. 
(a)  The completed tattoo shall be washed with a single-use towel saturated with an antibacterial solution. 
(b)  After the area has dried, apply a layer of antibacterial ointment from a single use dispenser or applicator. 
(c)  A bandage or cover shall then be applied to the tattoo using sealed telfa (non-sticking) pads. 
(d)  Verbal and written instructions, approved by the county health department for the care of the body art procedure site shall be provided to each client by the operator upon completion of the procedure. The written instructions shall advise the client to consult a physician at the first sign of infection and contain the name, address and phone number of the establishment. These documents shall be signed and dated by both parties, with a copy given to the client and the operator retaining the original with all other required records. The facility shall also post in public view the name, address and phone number of the county health department and the procedure for filing a complaint. The notice for filing a complaint shall be included in the establishment application packet. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-65. - Disinfection of workplace. 
Each body art studio must be kept clean and sanitary. The owner must develop and implement a cleaning schedule that includes appropriate methods of decontamination and tasks or procedures to be performed. This written schedule must be based on the location within the studio, the type of surfaces to be cleaned, type of possible contamination present, the tasks or procedures to be performed, and their location within the studio. 
The following procedures should be adhered to: 
(1)  Clean and sanitize all equipment and work surfaces with an appropriate disinfectant after completion of tattoo/body piercing procedures and at the end of work shift when surfaces have become contaminated since the last cleaning. 
(2)  Remove and replace protective coverings such as plastic wrap and aluminum foil after each tattoo procedure. 
(3)  Inspect and decontaminate, on a daily basis or more frequently if necessary, reusable receptacles such as bins, pails, and cans that have a likelihood for becoming contaminated. When contamination is visible, clean and decontaminate receptacles immediately, or as soon as feasible. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-66. - Disposal of waste. 
(a)  Needles, razors, or other sharp instruments used during tattoo/body piercing procedures, shall be placed in puncture resistant, closed containers immediately after use. 
(b)  Needles shall not be purposely bent or broken, or otherwise manipulated by hand. 
(c)  Containers of sharp waste shall be sent to a bio-hazardous waste facility where they are either incinerated or otherwise rendered non-hazardous in compliance with 29 CFR Part 1920.1030, occupational exposure to blood-borne pathogens. Record of disposal must be kept on site. 
(d)  Contaminated waste which may release liquid blood or body fluids when compressed or may release dried blood or body fluids when handled must be placed in an approved "red" bag, which is marked with the International Biohazard Symbol. It must then be disposed of in compliance with 29 Code of Federal Regulations Part 1910.1030, known as "Occupational Exposure To Blood-Borne Pathogens". Written documentation of how bio-waste is disposed of is required. 
(e)  Waste containers shall be kept closed when not in use. 
(f)  Disposable waste shall be handled, stored, and disposed of to minimize direct exposure of personnel to waste materials. 
(g)  At least one covered waste receptacle shall be provided in each operator area and each toilet room. Receptacles in the operator area shall be emptied daily and solid waste shall be removed from the premises at least weekly. All refuse containers shall be lidded, cleanable and kept clean. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-67. - Personnel. 
(a)  Persons performing the tattoo/body piercing operation shall obtain current certification in first aid and proof of attendance at a blood borne pathogen training program (or equivalent), given or approved by the county health department. Training/courses provided by professional body art organizations/associations or by equipment manufacturers may also be submitted for consideration. 
(b)  If the artist is currently in business at the time of application for permit the above certification must be obtained within 60 days from the date the permit is issued. 
(c)  Persons performing the tattoo/body piercing operation shall obtain current certification in CPR, and present proof of such training at the time of application. 
(d)  Proof shall be provided upon request that all tattoo artists and body piercing artists have either completed or were offered and declined in writing, the hepatitis B vaccination series; that antibody testing has revealed that the employee is immune to hepatitis B; or that the vaccine is contraindicated for medical reasons. Contraindication requires a dated and signed physician's statement specifying the name of the employee and that the vaccine cannot be given. 
(e)  No person shall perform or be involved with the tattoo/body piercing operation or procedure if such person has a skin rash, boils, infected wounds, open sores, weeping dermatological lesions, or acute respiratory infection. 
(f)  The owner or governing body must maintain a file on all employees who perform tattoo/body piercing procedures, which will be available for inspection and includes the following: 
(1)  Proof of immunization and immunity for Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B. Proof of negative HIV and RPR (syphilis) status. Yearly testing for immunity to hepatitis A and hepatitis B, HIV and RPR (syphilis) serology testing. 
(2)  Evidence of first aid certification and completed training in disease prevention/blood borne pathogens. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-68. - Client files. 
(a)  For each client, proper records of identification, tattoos/piercings administered, informed consent, and care instructions shall be kept and retained for a minimum of two years. 
(b)  Records of each client shall be prepared prior to the procedure being performed and shall reflect the client's name and signature, address, phone number, type of positive picture ID, proof of age, date tattooed, design, its location and name of the artist. 
(c)  A statement of informed consent by the individual receiving the tattoo must be maintained on file. 
(d)  A statement by the client attesting that he/she is not under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs shall be on file. 
(e)  A copy of procedures signed by the client advising them of proper subsequent care of the tattoo shall be maintained on file. 
(f)  A copy of instructions signed by the client informing them on the risks involved and possible complications that might result from the tattoo/body piercing procedure must be maintained on file. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-69. - Application for permit. 
(a)  The governing body of each body art studio shall submit to the county health department an application for a permit to operate under the rules and regulations. No studio shall be operated and no tattooing/body piercing performed without such a permit which is current under these rules and regulations. 
(b)  The application for permit shall be made on forms provided by the county board of health. 
(c)  Each application for a permit shall be accompanied by a floor sketch of the body art studio showing windows, doors, room measurements, chairs, tables and equipment placement for clients and/or staff. 
(d)  A listing of the names of all staff including the owner who will be working in the studio shall be included with the application for a permit. This listing shall include the full name of each staff person. 
(e)  The ownership of the studio shall be fully disclosed in its application for a permit. 
(f)  Zoning and other local requirements regarding proper location and establishment of body art studios shall be addressed by the applicant with the responsible local officials. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-70. - Operator/artist permit. 
(a)  No person shall practice body art procedures without first obtaining an operator/artist permit from the county health department. 
(b)  The operator/artist permit shall be valid from the date of issuance and shall automatically expire in one year and must be renewed annually unless revoked sooner by the department. 
(c)  Application for the operator/artist permits shall include: 
(1)  Name; 
(2)  Date of birth; 
(3)  Sex; 
(4)  Residence address; 
(5)  Mailing address; 
(6)  Phone number; 
(7)  Place(s) of employment as an operator/artist; 
(8)  Training and/or experience; 
(9)  Proof of attendance at a blood-borne pathogen training program and first aid course given or approved by the county board of health; 
(10)  Copy of driver's license or other pictured ID for purposes of identification; 
(11)  Copy of current cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) certificate or other evidence of completion of CPR training; 
(12)  The application fee charged by the county board of health; 
(13)  Proof regarding Hepatitis B as required by section 38-67(d); 
(14)  A physician's statement that all tattoo artists and body piercing artists are free from the following communicable diseases: 
a.  Hepatitis A and B; 
b.  Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS); 
c.  Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV); 
d.  Syphilis. 
(15)  Proof of contract or agreement with bio-hazardous waste facility for disposal as required by section 38-66(c). 
(d)  All operator/artist permits shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous area where they may be readily observed by clients. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-71. - Permit. 
(a)  The governing body of each body art studio shall obtain a valid permit from the county board of health prior to beginning operation. To be eligible for a permit the studio must be in compliance with these rules and regulations. 
(b)  The permit shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises. 
(c)  Permits are not transferable from one studio to another. 
(d)  A permit shall no longer be valid and shall be returned to the county board of health when the studio ceases to operate, has moved to another location, the ownership changes, or the permit is suspended or revoked. 
(e)  A studio which fails to comply with these rules and regulations shall be subject to the sanctions available to the county board of health pursuant to O.C.G.A. chapter 31-5 including, but not limited to, denial or revocation of its permit by the county board of health. 
(f)  No occupation tax certificate shall be issued by the city unless and until a permit required by this section is issued by the county board of health. Revocation of such permit by the county board of health shall be grounds for revocation of any occupation tax certificate issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-72. - Inspections. 
(a)  The studio and its records shall be available for review and examination by properly identified representatives of the county board of health and/or City of Sylvania police or city officials. 
(b)  A copy of the inspection report shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises and also shall be available for public inspection at the county health department where the studio is located. 
(c)  Body art studios shall be subject to inspection by the county health department and/or City of Sylvania police or city officials at all reasonable times, including regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-73. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Enforcement of these rules and regulations shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. chapter 31-5. 
(b)  No person shall engage in tattooing/body piercing except in a licensed studio. All tattoo artists must have an operator permit. No tattoo studio shall be operated without a permit. Failure or refusal to file an application for a permit shall constitute a violation of O.C.G.A. chapter 31-40. 
(c)  The county board of health may refuse to grant a permit for the operation of any body art studio that does not fulfill the minimum requirements of these rules and regulations and may revoke a permit which has been issued and invoke other sanctions if a studio violates any of these rules and regulations. Before any order is entered refusing a permit applied for or revoking a permit, the applicant or permit holder shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing before the county board as provided in O.C.G.A. chapter 31-5, article 1. The notice of refusal or revocation shall contain directions on how a hearing may be requested. 
(d)  The county board of health is empowered to institute appropriate proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction for the purpose of enjoining violation of any applicable provision of O.C.G.A. title 31, or of the rules and regulations. 
(e)  The city may contract with Screven County and/or the Screven County board of health to carry out the terms and provisions of this article. 
(f)  Violations of this article shall also subject the violator to the general penalty provisions set forth in section 1-12 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Sylvania as now enacted or subsequently amended. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-74. - Effective date. 
The ordinance from which this article is derived shall become effective upon adoption. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Sec. 38-75. - Severability. 
In the event any part or parts of this article are declared to be unconstitutional or unlawful by any court of competent jurisdiction, the offending portion or portions shall be deemed stricken herefrom, and the remaining part or parts of this article shall remain enforceable. 
(Ord. No. 474, 3-6-12) 
Chapter 42 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS[1]
