Chapter 46 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Listed below are section number designations from the 1976 Code which have been omitted from this codification as duplications of state law: 

 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; offenses, ch. 50; traffic and vehicles, ch. 70. 
State Law reference— Establishment and jurisdiction of municipal courts, Ga. Const. art. 6, sec. 1, par. 1; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 46-1—46-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BONDS 

Sec. 46-26. - Appearance bonds. 
The municipal court of the city shall have the power and authority to accept cash bonds in an amount not to exceed the maximum fine that may be imposed by law for the offense or offenses charged, or a property bond in an amount not to exceed double the amount of the maximum fine that may be imposed for the charge or charges. Additionally, the municipal court shall have the authority to release persons on their own recognizance only, and the full power and authority to issue an order for the arrest of persons charged with crimes who fail to appear for arraignment, trial, or other hearing before the court at the appointed time. Appearance bonds may be set and accepted by the municipal judge of the city or his designee, or by the chief of police of the city, or his designee. Additionally, the municipal judge shall have all powers conferred upon municipal court judges by state law as presently existing or hereinafter enacted. 
(Ord. No. 392, § II, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 46-27. - When forfeiture occurs. 
(a)  A bond forfeiture occurs at the end of the court day upon the failure of appearance of a principal of any bond or recognizance given for the appearance of that person. 
(b)  An appearance bond shall not be forfeited unless the clerk of the court gave the surety at least 72 hours' written notice, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, before the time of the required appearance of the principal. Notice shall not be necessary if the time for appearance is within 72 hours from the time of arrest, provided the time for appearance is stated on the bond, or where the principal is given actual notice in open court. 
(Ord. No. 392, § II, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 46-28. - Execution hearing on failure to appear. 
(a)  The judge shall, at the end of the court day, upon the failure of the principal to appear, forfeit the bond and order an execution hearing not sooner than 120 days but not later than 150 days after such failure to appear. Notice of the execution hearing shall be served within ten days of such failure to appear by certified mail to the surety at the address listed on the bond or by personal service to the surety within ten days of such failure to appear at its home office or to its designated registered agent. Service shall be considered complete upon the mailing of such certified notice. 
(b)  If at the execution hearing it is determined that judgment should be entered, the judge shall so order and a writ of fieri facias shall be filed on the execution docket of the clerk of the superior court of Screven County, Georgia. Said judgment may be also entered on the execution docket in other counties of the State of Georgia, and in states outside the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 392, § II, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 46-29. - Conditions not warranting forfeiture of bond for failure to appear; remission of forfeiture. 
(a)  No judgment shall be rendered on a forfeiture of any appearance bond if it is shown to the satisfaction of the court by the written statement of a licensed physician that the principal on the bond was prevented from attending by some mental or physical disability. 
(b)  No judgment shall be rendered on a forfeiture of any appearance bond if it is shown to the satisfaction of the court that the principal on the bond was prevented from attending because he or she was detained by reason of arrest, sentence, or confinement in a penal institution or jail in the State of Georgia, or so detained in another jurisdiction, or because he or she was involuntarily confined or detained pursuant to court order in a mental institution in the State of Georgia or in another jurisdiction. An official written notice of the holding institution in which the principal is being detained or confined shall be considered proof of the principal's detention or confinement and such notice may be sent from the holding institution by mail or delivered by hand or by facsimile machine. Upon the presentation of such written notice to the clerk of the city municipal court and to the city chief of police, along with a letter of intent to pay all costs of returning the principal to the jurisdiction of the court, such notice and letter shall serve as the surety's request for a detainer or hold to be placed on the principal. Should there be a failure to place a detainer or hold within 15 days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, and after such presentation of such notice and letter of intent to pay costs, the surety shall then be relieved of the liability for the appearance bond without further order of the court. 
(c)  No judgment shall be rendered on a forfeiture of any appearance bond if it is shown to the satisfaction of the court that prior to the entry of the judgment on the forfeiture the principal on the bond is in the custody of the city chief of police or other responsible law enforcement agency. An official written notice of the holding institution in which the principal is being detained or confined shall be considered proof of the principal's detention or confinement and such notice may be sent from the holding institution by mail or delivered by hand or by facsimile machine. Upon the presentation of such written notice to the clerk of the city municipal court and the city chief of police, along with a letter of intent to pay all costs of returning the principal to the jurisdiction of the court, such notice and letter shall serve as the surety's request for a detainer or hold to be placed against the principal. Should there be a failure to place a detainer or hold within 15 days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, and after presentation of such notice and letter of intent to pay costs, the surety shall then be relieved of the liability for the appearance bond without further order of the court. 
(d)  In cases in which subsection (d)(3) of this section is not applicable, on application filed within 120 days from the payment of judgment, the court shall order remission under the following conditions: 
(1)  Provided the bond amount has been paid within 120 days after judgment and the delay has not prevented prosecution of the principal and upon application to the city municipal court, said court shall direct remission of 95 percent of the bond amount remitted to the surety if the surety locates the principal in the custody of the city chief of police, the sheriff in the jurisdiction where the bond was made, or in another jurisdiction causing the return of the principal to the city chief of police, apprehends, surrenders, or produces the principal, if the apprehension or surrender of the principal was substantially procured or caused by the surety, or if the location of the principal by the surety caused the adjudication of the principal in the city municipal court or Screven County State Court. Should the surety, within two years of the principal's failure to appear, locate the principal in the custody of the chief of police of Sylvania, the sheriff in the jurisdiction where the bond was made or in another jurisdiction causing the return of the principal to the chief of police of Sylvania, apprehend, surrender, or produce the principal, if the apprehension or surrender of the principal is substantially procured or caused by the surety, or if the location of the principal by the surety causes the adjudication of the principal in the municipal court of the city or the State Court of Screven County, the surety shall be entitled to a refund of 50 percent of the bond amount. The application for 50 percent remission shall be filed no later than 30 days following the expiration of the two-year period following the date of judgment; 
(2)  Remission shall be granted upon condition of the payment of court costs and of the expenses of returning the principal to the jurisdiction by the surety; or 
(3)  If, within 120 days after judgment, the surety surrenders the principal to the chief of police or responsible law enforcement officer, or said surrender has been denied by the chief of police or responsible law enforcement officer, or surety located the principal in custody in another jurisdiction, the surety shall only be required to pay costs and five percent of the face amount of the bond, which amount includes all surcharges. If it is shown to the satisfaction of the court, by the presentation of competent evidence from the chief of police or the holding institution, that said surrender has been made or denied or that the principal is in custody in another jurisdiction or that said surrender has been made and that five percent of the face amount of the bond and all costs have been tendered to the chief of police, the court shall direct that the judgment be marked satisfied and that the writ of execution, fi. fa., be canceled. 
(Ord. No. 392, § II, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 46-30. - Address of principal and surety on bond or recognizance. 
Every bond or recognizance given to secure the appearance of any person in any criminal proceeding shall have entered thereon the mailing address of the principal and each surety. 
(Ord. No. 392, § II, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 46-31. - Effective date. 
This article shall be effective February 15, 2000. Provided, however, any cash or property bonds previously accepted by any person on behalf of the city may be forfeited under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 392, § II, 2-15-00) 
Chapter 50 - OFFENSES[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— General penalty, § 1-12; alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; health and sanitation, ch. 38; municipal court, ch. 46; solid waste, ch. 58; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; traffic and vehicles, ch. 70. 
State Law reference— Limitations on home rule powers of municipal corporations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 50-1. - Intoxicating beverages prohibited at recreation center. 
No person shall consume, or have in his possession for consumption, any intoxicating beverages of any kind, character or description upon the property of the city used for recreational purposes and generally designated as the recreation center. 
(Code 1976, § 4-4001) 
Sec. 50-2. - Electric fences prohibited. 
No electric fence shall be erected or placed within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 1, 8-21-84) 
Sec. 50-3. - Attempt to commit offense. 
Whoever attempts to commit any offense prohibited by this Code, and in this attempt does any act toward the commission of this offense, but fails in the perpetration thereof, or is intercepted or prevented in the execution thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1001) 
Sec. 50-4. - Begging. 
No person shall beg, solicit or obtain alms or gifts, directly or indirectly, for the use of the solicitor or beggar, within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1002) 
Sec. 50-5. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  Any person shall be guilty of disorderly conduct if he: 
(1)  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby any person is placed in fear of safety for his life, limb or health. 
(2)  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby public property or property of any other person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged. 
(3)  Endangers lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, angry threats and abusive conduct. 
(4)  Causes, provokes or engages in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another or public property. 
(5)  Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking or engaging in any fight or brawl. 
(6)  Jostles or roughly crowds or pushes any person in any public place. 
(7)  Collects in bodies or in crowds for unlawful purposes. 
(8)  Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of or with the intent to engage in gaming. 
(9)  Frequents any public place with intent to obtain money from another by an illegal and fraudulent scheme, trick, artifice or device. 
(10)  Assembles with another or others for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in the city, or aids or abets therein. 
(11)  Utters, while in a state of anger, in the presence of another, any lewd or obscene words or epithets. 
(12)  Frequents any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated. 
(13)  Acts in a dangerous manner toward others. 
(14)  Uses "fighting words" directed towards any person who becomes outraged and thus creates turmoil. 
(15)  Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of doing bodily harm to another. 
(16)  By acts of violence, interferes with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation. 
(17)  Congregates with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuses to clear such public way when ordered to do so by a peace officer or other person having authority. 
(18)  Makes any unreasonably loud and unnecessary noise. 
(19)  Damages, befouls or disturbs public property or the property of another so as to create a hazardous, unhealthy or physically offensive condition. 
(20)  Consumes alcoholic beverages on any public street, sidewalk, or any other public property within the corporate limits of the city. Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages or containers with the seal broken shall be prima facie evidence of consumption. 
(21)  Consumes alcoholic beverages in a vehicle or not on any public or private parking lot within the corporate limits of the city, except those maintained at establishments holding a valid on-premises license for the retail sale of malt beverages. Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages or containers with the seal broken shall be prima facie evidence of consumption. 
(22)  Any person convicted of disorderly conduct, as defined in this section, shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1004) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
Sec. 50-6. - Indecency. 
No person shall be found in a state of nudity, or in dress not appropriate to his sex, or indecently expose his person, or make any indecent gesture. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1005) 
Sec. 50-7. - Loitering in parks. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall loiter in any park within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(b)  Public parks located in residential areas. 
(1)  Loitering prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in any public park located in areas within the city zoned R-1, R-2 or R-3 between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  Notice. The city manager shall cause to be posted in each and every public park located in areas within the city zoned R-1, R-2 or R-3, a sign in a conspicuous location within such parks, containing the following language: 
PARK HOURS: 6:00 A.M.—9:00 P.M.  LOITERING IN PARK IS UNLAWFUL  BETWEEN 9:00 P.M. AND 6:00 A.M.  MAXIMUM FINE: $500.00 
(3)  Enforcement. Anyone violating the provisions of this subsection shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $25.00 for the first offense, and not to exceed $500.00 or six months imprisonment, or both, for subsequent offenses. 
(4)  Conflict with other ordinances. To the extent that this subsection is in conflict with subsection 50-7(a) and section 50-19, this subsection shall supersede such other sections. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1006; Ord. No. 358, §§ I—IV, 10-13-97) 
Cross reference— Curfew for minors in parks, § 50-19(a). 
Sec. 50-8. - Loitering in streets, other public places. 
(a)  No person shall loiter upon the streets, sidewalks or other public places within the city without apparent reason and under circumstances which justify suspicion that he may be engaged in or about to engage in a crime. 
(b)  No person shall loiter in or near the city hall. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1007) 
Sec. 50-9. - Profane language. 
No person shall use profane, vulgar, indecent or obscene language in any public place or publicly; or upon the private premises of another, or so near thereto as to be heard by another. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1008) 
Sec. 50-10. - Unlawful assemblies. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to assemble with others for the purpose of doing or committing any unlawful act, whether the same is contrary to the laws of the state or the United States or this Code or an ordinance of the city, or a lawful act designed to provoke a breach of the peace or other civil disorder, to fail and refuse to obey the lawful order or command of any police, constable or other peace officer to disperse, separate and move on from the scene of such unlawful assembly. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1009) 
Sec. 50-11. - Discharge of airgun, slingshots. 
No person shall discharge any airgun or slingshot within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1010) 
Sec. 50-12. - Discharge of firearms, bows and arrows. 
(a)  No person shall discharge any gun, pistol or other firearm or bow and arrow without written permission from the chief of police containing a statement as to duration of such permission and a statement as to the purpose and circumstances for which such permission is granted. Permission may be granted for such purposes which shall include, but shall not be limited to, the disposal of poisonous and otherwise harmful snakes; the disposal of squirrels which are causing health hazards or damage to property; and the disposal of other vermin which are harmful to health or property. Permission shall only be granted to those persons who, in the sole discretion of the chief of police, are responsible adults. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  To any authorized federal, state, county or municipal officer in the legitimate pursuit of his duties nor to one exercising his right of self defense as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 16-3-21; 
(2)  To archery classes conducted under the supervision of the county board of education or its duly authorized personnel; 
(3)  To any person who, with permission of the owner, is hunting or conducting target practice on a tract of land within the city which has acreage within the city equaling or exceeding 20 acres. This exception is subject to all other state, federal and local laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1011; Ord. No. 246, 1-22-85; Ord. No. 288, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 435, § I, 9-7-06) 
Sec. 50-13. - Officers to take possession of weapons of arrested persons. 
If any person is lawfully arrested while committing a criminal offense or a breach or disturbance of the public peace and shall have on his person any dangerous weapon, the arresting officer shall take possession of this weapon. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1012) 
Sec. 50-14. - Use of weapons by minors. 
(a)  No minor shall discharge any gun, pistol, air rifle, BB gun, pellet gun, or any other weapons of like nature in the city. 
(b)  Once a minor has been charged with a violation of subsection (a), the subject weapon or weapons shall be confiscated by law enforcement officials pending trial. 
(c)  Any adult who shall intentionally or negligently encourage or acquiesce in the violation of subsection (a) shall be subject in the penalties set out in section 1-12 upon conviction. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1013; Ord. No. 247, 1-22-85) 
Sec. 50-15. - Unauthorized use of trash dumpster. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
Commercial trash dumpster means a receptacle for trash, garbage or other refuse of the variety commonly referred to as a dumpster, for which a specially designed truck is generally used in dumping such receptacle. 
Owner means a person having title to or having a valid lease on a commercial trash dumpster. 
(b)  Unauthorized use of trash dumpster prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit trash, garbage or other refuse, or any other item or items, into a commercial trash dumpster in the city without the express consent of the owner. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 283, § 3, 12-1-87) 
Sec. 50-16. - Interference with public monuments prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, sit on, stand on or hang from any statue, monument, tombstone, public fountain or memorial erected in public parks, government-owned cemeteries and other public property within the city. 
(b)  Violations of this section shall be tried in the municipal court and shall be punishable upon conviction, as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 290, 7-5-88) 
Sec. 50-17. - Solicitors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person not a resident of the city to solicit the sale of magazines, pictures, pencils or other miscellaneous items within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-4002) 
Sec. 50-18. - Distribution of printed material prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed within the city any handbill or printed or written material by placing, or causing such handbill or printed or written material to be placed in any yards, driveways, walkways or porches of any structure within the city. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any newspaper, or to any publication containing printed or written material, to which the occupants of the subject premises pay money (United States currency) in return for receiving such material. 
(c)  This section is not intended nor shall it be construed to prohibit distribution of printed or written material utilizing any means of distribution which does not cause such materials to be placed or deposited in any yards, driveways, walkways or porches of any structure within the city which means of distribution shall include, but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  The U.S. mail. 
(2)  Personally handing such material to persons willing to accept the same on streets, sidewalks, parks or at their residences. 
(3)  Utilizing doorknobs or mailbox hanging devices in a manner which reasonably ensures that such material shall not be placed or caused to become placed or deposited upon any yards, driveways or porches of any structure within the city. 
(d)  Violations of this section shall be punishable upon conviction, as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 321, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 323, 7-28-92) 
Sec. 50-19. - Curfew for minors; penalty for parents, guardians, etc., for violations. 
(a)  Curfew after 11:00 p.m. for persons 17 years or younger. It is unlawful for any minor 17 years of age or younger to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; however, on Fridays and Saturdays, the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his or her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity or dance; 
(4)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above referenced places during the proscribed period of time; 
(5)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion. 
(b)  Responsibility of parents. It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other person having custody or control of any child 17 years of age or younger to permit or by insufficient control to allow such child to be in or upon the public streets or any other places listed in subsection (a) within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day, or on Fridays and Saturdays between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. the following day, except in circumstances set out in subsections (1) through (5) of subsection (a). Upon conviction of violation of this section for the first time, a person shall be given a warning citation. Upon further convictions, a person shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00 and costs, or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than 60 days, or work on the public streets or work on the public works of the city for not more than 60 days, or be subject to any one or more of the punishments, subject to all limitations contained in the Charter of the city. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 329, § III, 9-28-93) 
Cross reference— Loitering in parks, § 50-7. 
Sec. 50-20. - Maintenance of yards on residential lots. 
(a)  Grassy areas. It shall be unlawful for the adult occupant or occupants of any residential structure in the city, the property owner or owners of any unoccupied residential structure in the city, or the owner or owners of any vacant lot in an area zoned R-1, R-2 or R-3 in the city that has been substantially cleared of trees and is no longer in a natural wooded state to allow the grass in any portion of the yard area to exceed a height of six inches for a period of longer than three weeks. 
(b)  Beds of flowers, trees or shrubbery. It shall be unlawful for the adult occupant or occupants of any occupied residential structure in the city, or the property owner or owners of any unoccupied residential structure in the city or the owner or owners of any vacant lot in an area zoned R-1, R-2 or R-3 in the city that has been substantially cleared of trees and is no longer in a natural wooded state to allow weeds and other undergrowth to exceed a height of six inches for a period of longer than three weeks in any portion of the yard area containing beds of flowers, trees or shrubbery. 
(c)  Definition of yard. For purposes of this section, "yard" is defined to mean all of the area surrounding a residential structure, located on one lot or on contiguous lots owned by the same owner or owners, or occupied by the same occupant or occupants of the residential structure, but excluding any portion of such lot or lots which are uncleared and have been left in a natural wooded state. "Yard" also includes vacant lots in areas of the city zoned R-1, R-2 and R-3 which have been substantially cleared of trees and are no longer in a natural wooded state. 
(d)  Exception for occupants of multifamily structures. This section shall be applicable to the owners of multifamily residential structures (apartments, duplexes and condominiums) and shall not be applicable to the occupants of such multifamily residential structures. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person or persons violating the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $25.00 for the first offense. Subsequent offenses shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $100.00. After the receipt of a warning or citation from the city police department or other peace officer that this section is being violated, each additional day that this section is violated shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 331, §§ III—VI, 11-16-93) 
Cross reference— Weed and vegetation growth as nuisances, § 30-26; dilapidated buildings as nuisances, § 30-41 et seq.; salvage yards as nuisances, § 30-61. 
Sec. 50-21. - Maintenance of yards on commercial lots. 
(a)  Definitions. [For the purposes of this section the following definitions apply:] 
Occupant shall mean any natural person, corporation, partnership, firm or association, or other legal entity that occupies real estate subject to this section as a tenant, either gratuitously, or for a valid consideration. 
Owner shall mean any natural person, corporation, partnership, firm or association, or other legal entity that has any ownership interest in real estate subject to this section. 
Yard shall mean all of the area on one lot or on contiguous lots owned by the same owner or owners in a commercial zone within the city (C-1 or C-2) or in a professional zone (P) that is not covered by a building or by paving, but excluding any portion of such lot or lots which are uncleared and have been left in a natural wooded state. "Yard" also includes vacant lots in areas of the city zoned C-1, C-2 and P which have been substantially cleared of trees and are no longer in a natural wooded state. 
(b)  Yard standards. 
(1)  Grassy areas. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of real estate zoned C-1, C-2 or P in the city, or the owner or owners of any vacant real estate in an area zoned C-1, C-2 or P in the city that has been substantially cleared of trees and is no longer in a natural wooded state, to allow the grass in any portion of the yard to exceed a height of six inches for a period of longer than three weeks. 
(2)  Beds. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of real estate zoned C-1, C-2 or P in the city, or the owner or owners of any vacant real estate in an area zoned C-1, C-2, or P in the city that has been substantially cleared of trees and is no longer in a natural wooded state, to allow weeds and other undergrowth to exceed a height of six inches for a period of longer than three weeks in any portion of the yard containing beds or flowers, trees or shrubbery. 
(3)  Trash dumpsters. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of real estate in any zone in the city on which there is situated a commercial solid waste container to allow trash, garbage or other refuse to be placed in such container in such a manner that such trash, garbage or other refuse falls from the confines of such container due to force of wind, gravity, or a combination of both. 
(c)  Penalty. Any owner or occupant violating the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $25.00 for the first offense. Subsequent offenses shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $100.00. After receipt of a warning or citation from the city police department or other peace officer that this section is being violated, each additional day that the section is violated shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 342, §§ III—V, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 50-22. - Probationers in municipal court to provide information. 
Some of the persons who are given probated sentences in the Sylvania Municipal Court abscond during the probationary period. The purpose of this section is to require probationers to provide information regarding their whereabouts and to provide for the tolling of sentences for absconding probationers. 
(1)  Information regarding whereabouts. Where all or any part of a sentence rendered in the municipal court of the city is probated, the probationer shall keep the city police chief, or his designee, informed at all times during the probation period of the probationer's residential address and his whereabouts. 
(2)  Tolling of sentence. In the event the probationer cannot be found at his residential address or at a location provided by the probationer to the chief of police or his designee, upon the filing of an affidavit in the city municipal court to that effect, the sentence given to the probationer shall be tolled during the period beginning with the filing of the affidavit, through the date that the probationer reports to the chief of police or his designee, or the probationer is taken into custody by the city, or the probationer otherwise makes himself available to the city municipal court. 
(3)  Power to revoke probation. The municipal court of the city shall have the power to revoke all or any part of a probated sentence for violation of any term or terms of the conditions of probation imposed by the court. 
(4)  Unpaid fines, etc. Any unpaid fines, restitution, or any other monies owed as a condition of probation shall be due when the probationer first reports to the chief of police or his designee after the filing of an affidavit as provided in subsection (2) above, or upon the probationer being taken into custody by the city, or upon the probationer otherwise making himself available to the municipal court for the city. Provided however, if the entire balance of the probationer's probation is revoked, all conditions of probation, including monies owed, shall be negated by his imprisonment. Provided further, if only a part of the balance of the probation is revoked, the probationer shall still be responsible for the full amount of the unpaid fines, restitution, and other monies upon his return to probation after release from imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 362, §§ I—IV, 11-3-98; Ord. No. 390, 2-15-00) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 362, §§ I—IV, adopted Nov. 3, 1998, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion as § 50-22 was at the editor's discretion. 
Chapter 54 - SIGNS[1]
