The former chapter 58 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1976, §§ 4-2001—4-2004, 4-2006; Ord. No. 259, § 1, adopted Dec. 30, 1985; Ord. No. 348, §§ I—IX, adopted Nov. 18, 1996; Ord. No. 350, §§ I—III, adopted Dec. 16, 1996; Ord. No. 351, adopted Dec. 16, 1996. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; health and sanitation, ch. 38; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; offenses, ch. 50; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 74. 
State Law reference— Authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3; Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; hazardous waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-61 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries pursuant to contract, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
[For the purposes of this chapter the following definitions apply:] 
All other refuse includes tin cans and such other materials as may not be classified under other heads. 
Ashes means the refuse from fires in houses, schools, stores, etc. They include at times small quantities of glass, crockery, sweepings, dust, brick, metal and other inorganic materials. 
Carts shall mean trash receptacles provided by the city. 
Commercial solid waste shall mean all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other non-manufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. 
Composting shall mean the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. 
Garbage means the organic waste both animal and vegetable from house, kitchen, restaurants, hotels, hospitals, etc. It is comprised chiefly of waste food and shall not include liquid that may be drained into the sewer. 
Leachate collection system shall mean a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. 
Municipal solid waste shall mean any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multi-family residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. 
Municipal solid waste disposal facility shall mean any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. 
Municipal solid waste landfill shall mean a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, non-hazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. 
Occupant shall mean persons over the age of 18 years residing in a residence within the city; owners of businesses in the city, including, and without limitation, sole proprietors, shareholders in a corporation, and general partners in a partnership; and onsite managers of businesses within the city. 
Yard trimmings shall mean leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-2. - Fees for collection. 
Garbage collection fees shall be as fixed and established from time to time by the mayor and council, and the schedule of fees shall be on file in the office of the city clerk; provided, that no change in any fee shown on the schedule shall be effective without prior advertisement at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Provided further, every residence, business establishment or service agency within the limits of the city and to which garbage and solid waste collection and disposal services are available, shall pay a fee for the availability of such service, regardless of whether the residence, business or agency use the service, and the fee shall be based upon said fee schedule. All garbage charges to a complex of apartments, houses, mobile homes or business will be billed to the landlord of the property, and the landlord shall be responsible to the city for the payment of assessed charges. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-3. - Garbage required to be promptly removed. 
No garbage that has become decayed or that shall otherwise be a menace to health or cleanliness shall be allowed to remain in any dwelling house, hotel, boardinghouse, cafe, restaurant, lunch stand, fruit stand, meat market, store or other building or on any premises a longer time than shall be reasonably necessary to remove and deposit it in a receptacle or receptacles as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-4. - Collection, transportation of garbage by private persons. 
No person shall collect, handle, haul or transport, on any of the streets, alleys, public ways or places of the city, any garbage without first having procured a permit therefor from the city manager or his representative, and from the State Department of Natural Resources. Any vehicle to be used for the purpose of hauling or transporting garbage shall first be approved by the city manager or his representative and shall be at all times subject to his inspection as to condition and cleanliness. All garbage hauled in these vehicles shall be hauled in closed containers. Persons having a permit for hauling garbage under the provisions of this section shall place daily at each hotel, cafe, cafeteria or restaurant or other place from which this garbage is to be hauled a clean empty can furnished by this person or by the operator of this hotel, cafe, cafeteria or restaurant, for the garbage; and each can shall be removed not later than the following day, Sundays excepted, without changing the contents thereof. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-5. - Removal of garbage, ashes and refuse by city. 
Garbage, ashes and refuse will be collected and removed on the days fixed therefor by the city manager. Public notice shall be given of any change in collection days. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Secs. 58-6—58-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PREPARATION FOR COLLECTION AND COLLECTION 
DIVISION 1. - GARBAGE COLLECTION 

Sec. 58-20. - Cart system. 
Placement and removal of carts. Occupants shall place garbage for curbside pick up in carts provided by the city. On the evening before each day assigned by the city for collection in the occupant's area, the cart will be placed on the curb, in front of the premises from which it is to be collected or on the curb at the side of the premises where the premises are adjacent to more than one street, as close to the curb line or edge of roadway as practicable. The cart should be placed no earlier than 5:00 p.m. for pick up the next day or later than 8:00 a.m. on the day of pick up. The cart will be removed from the curbside point by the occupant no later than 8:00 a.m. on the day after the assigned collection date. At other times, carts will be stored by the occupant where possible in locations not visible from the street or road on which the garbage is collected. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-21. - Cost of carts. 
The city shall initially provide and bear the cost of the first cart for each residence and business. In the event the cart is insufficient to contain the garbage for a residence or business, the occupant shall bear the cost of placement of an additional cart at the residence or business, which cart shall be provided by the city. In the event a cart is lost, stolen or abused, the occupant shall bear the cost of replacement. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-22. - Removal by city. 
In the event the cart is not used for a period of three weeks, the city shall have the right to remove the cart from the residence or business. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-23. - Physical handicaps. 
If there is no occupant of the residence or business who is physically capable of complying with the requirements of section 58-20 above, regarding the placement and removal of carts at curbside, the occupant or occupants of such residence or business shall be exempted from such requirements upon written approval of the city manager. The city manager may require such proof of disability as he, in his sole discretion, deems sufficient, including but not limited to a signed statement from a medical doctor. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-24. - Schedules. 
Assigned collection dates, fees and costs for carts, and fees and costs for collection and disposal service shall be contained on a schedule approved by the city council and kept on file with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-25. - Damage or destruction of carts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or destroy any cart provided by the city pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-26. - Yard debris. 
No tree trimmings, grass, or other bulky materials shall be placed in carts. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-27. - Sidewalks and streets. 
No householder or business operator, by himself or agent, shall sweep from any house, yard, store or elsewhere any dirt or refuse in or upon the sidewalk or public street, but all refuse shall be placed in carts as herein provided. No person shall place any tree trimmings or other material in any sidewalk area or in the vehicular portion of any street or alley. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-28. - Building materials. 
All refuse resulting from building, repairing, remodeling or any type of construction or demolition should be removed by the contractor, owner of the property, or person having such work done. The city shall not remove refuse of this nature. Examples are lumber, shingles, carpet, tile and brick. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-29. - Trees, shrubbery, branches, yard trimmings, etc. 
All individuals, firms, businesses, partnerships, proprietorships or corporations engaged in the business of yard maintenance, landscaping, nursery operation or in the business of trimming or removing trees, shrubbery, or similar growth, who shall contract with the property owner, the owner's agent or occupant to perform services on the property shall remove from the property all yard trimmings, sawdust, branches, stumps and all portions of the byproducts of the services performed, as well as all rubbish associated therewith including rocks, concrete, dirt and trimmings. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-30. - Removal for compensation. 
It shall be unlawful for any firm, partnership, proprietorship or corporation to trim trees or bushes, do landscaping or yard work for compensation within the city unless the byproduct from those services is immediately removed from the premises and placed or deposited by the contractor in the city designated landfill or hauling station. Compensation shall be interpreted to include receiving as compensation the wood, limbs and other residue from such trimming and cutting. Any form of compensation shall place the burden of disposal directly upon the individual or contractor performing the task. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-31. - Tires. 
It shall be the responsibility of the owner or lessee of the property to properly dispose of tires in accordance with state and federal law. The city shall not remove or dispose of tires. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
DIVISION 2. - YARD TRIMMINGS AND OTHER COLLECTION 

Sec. 58-32. - Placement and disposal of yard trimmings; prohibitions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the city. 
(b)  Yard trimmings shall not be disposed at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-33. - Sorting, storing, composting and collecting yard trimmings. 
Yard trimmings and other bulky material shall be placed on the street curb in order that they may be removed without the collector going into the yard or place of business, and any exceptions to this subsection shall be determined at the discretion of the city manager. The city manager shall establish fixed days for the removal of this material and so publish the schedule. Yard trimmings for street pick up should be separated as follows: 
(1)  Leaves, straw, grass clippings. 
(2)  Limbs placed with butts toward street. 
(3)  Shrubbery trimmings and vines. 
(4)  All metals including appliances. 
(5)  Furniture (tables, chairs, sofas, etc.). 
(6)  Paper, plastic, cardboard. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-34. - Large loads. 
There shall be a fee for curbside collection of materials described in section 58-33 where the cumulative total of such materials exceeds the following: (a) 400 lbs. for any combination of metals, including appliances, furniture, paper, plastic, cardboard or tree trunks and stumps over 8 inches in diameter; or (b) 5 cubic yards for any combination of leaves, straw, grass clippings, limbs, and shrubbery trimmings and vines. The fee shall be set forth on a schedule that shall be kept on file at city hall, as amended from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-35. - Household furniture and appliances. 
Upon request, the city shall collect normal household furniture and appliances, including sofas, chairs, beds, refrigerators, washers, dryers, hot water heaters and similar items, but not including furnaces. Persons requesting this service shall notify the office of the director of public works or his or her designee as to the date collection will occur. The city shall have the right to set and collect a fee for this service. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-36. - Prohibited activities. 
The following activities are hereby declared to be unlawful and in violation of this chapter: 
(1)  Public streets and private property. No person shall place any accumulations of refuse and trash in any street, median strip, alley or other public place of travel, nor upon any private property, except with the written consent thereof and then only in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Blockage of drainage. At no time shall trash be placed in a manner as to obstruct drains, utility meters, walkways or streets. It shall be unlawful to use brooms, rakes, blowers or other sweeping, raking or debris removal tools or equipment so as to sweep, rake, blow or otherwise deposit or accumulate trash, garbage, gardening residue, clippings, limbs, ashes, alluvium, sediment or debris of any kind in or on city streets, walkways, drains, pipes or gutters. It shall be unlawful to place, accumulate or otherwise deposit any type of the aforementioned debris or material into a city drain, pipe, gutter or other draining conduit or receptacle. 
(3)  Unauthorized storage. Any accumulation of refuse or trash items on any lot, property, premises, public streets, alley or other public or private place not permitted by this article, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Failure of owner or occupant to remove and correct any such accumulation of refuse after appropriate notice from the director of public works shall raise the presumption that such person intended to violate this article. 
(4)  Junk. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave outside any building or dwelling, except as specified in section 66-24, any dilapidated furniture, appliance, machinery equipment, building material, junked motor vehicle, tires or other items which are either in a partially used, wrecked, junked, dismantled or inoperative condition, and which are not completely enclosed within a building or dwelling. 
(5)  Sweeping and blowing. It shall be unlawful to sweep or blow with a blower, grass clippings, leaves and other debris onto a city sidewalk or street. 
(6)  Dumping. It shall be unlawful and in violation of this section to dump, place or leave bricks, blocks, rocks, lumber, asphalt, cement, concrete, concrete products or waste, roofing, sheetrock, leaves, limbs, bushes, trees, roots, dead animals, appliances, equipment, bed springs, mattresses, furniture, fixtures, motors, engines' chemical wastes, industrial or commercial waste or rubbish, scrap metal, fence wire, vehicles or parts thereof, tires, building materials or supplies, and inorganic solid material of any type or kind except as authorized herein. 
(7)  Fires. It shall be unlawful and in violation of this chapter to set any fire, to allow a fire to continue to burn, or in any other way attempt to damage or destroy the garbage and solid waste collection containers provided by the city. 
(8)  Container of another. It shall be unlawful and in violation of this chapter for any person to dump, place or leave any item at a garbage and solid waste collection area or in any collection container unless such person has permission of the owner and/or occupant of the premises on which the area or container is located. 
(9)  Billboards. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for owners to fail to maintain billboards in a manner that prevents loose paper, bills and other litter and debris resulting from the use of such signs and billboards. Any such debris, loose papers, bills and other litter shall be removed by the owners or their agents immediately upon accumulation. 
b.  Any such item or items which remain on the property of the occupant for a period of 30 days after notice of violation of this article, shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the city without further notice. The city may charge the owner or occupant a fee for the cost to removing such item or items. This section shall not apply to licensed junk dealers or currently licensed establishments engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning, or salvaging of equipment or furniture. 
(10)  Scavenging. No person other than the owner thereof or an agent or employee of the director shall disturb or interfere with any container used for the purpose of storing refuse pending its collection, remove any contents therefrom, or remove such container from its collection. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-37. - Abandonment. 
Any such item or items which remain on the property of the occupant for a period of 30 days after notice of violation of this article, shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the city without further notice. The city may charge the owner or occupant a fee for the cost of removing such item or items. In the event the owner is also the occupant of the premises, any unpaid charge for removal may be collected by the city clerk in the same manner as delinquent taxes. This section shall not apply to licensed junk dealers or currently licensed establishments engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning, or salvaging of equipment or furniture. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Secs. 58-38—58-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 58-40. - Generally. 
All commercial establishments shall store their refuse in containers, as specified in this article, so as to eliminate wind-driven debris and unsightly litter in and about their establishments. Approved methods of containerization shall include refuse receptacles, bulk containers and detachable containers. Any spillage or overflow shall be immediately cleaned up by such establishment. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-41. - Loading and unloading areas. 
All loading and unloading areas shall be provided with refuse receptacles for loose debris, paper, packaging materials and other trash. The owner or occupant of the commercial establishment shall place a sufficient number of containers in such area to maintain a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. The number of such containers to be placed in service for a particular establishment shall be set by the director of public works. The number of such containers to be placed in service for a particular occupant of the premises shall maintain surveillance to insure that all litter is placed in the proper container and the area is kept clean. If the occupant violates this section, collection service may be suspended by the director of public works until such time as the owner or occupant of the premises brings such premises into full compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-42. - Construction sites and demolition sites. 
All construction and demolition contractors shall provide on-site refuse receptacles, bulk containers, or detachable containers for loose debris, paper, building material waste, scrap building materials and other trash (no hazardous waste shall be deposited in the containers) produced by those working at the construction site. A separate container shall be provided for metal scraps free of all other debris at the construction site. The site shall be kept in a litter-free condition. The number of refuse receptacles (not to exceed four or bulk containers, or detachable containers), shall be determined by the size of the job. Dirt, mud, construction materials or other debris upon any public or private property belonging to a person other than the owner of the construction site shall be removed by the designated collection contractor upon completion of the construction. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-43. - Use of dumpsters. 
The provisions of this chapter regarding use of carts shall not apply to any businesses, industries, or apartment buildings or structures within the city that have been approved by the city manager or his designee to utilize dumpsters. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Secs. 58-44—58-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPECIAL REFUSE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 58-50. - Industrial waste. 
Industrial waste shall be collected, removed and disposed of by any factory, plant or enterprise creating or causing such waste. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-51. - Hazardous refuse. 
No hazardous refuse shall be placed in any receptacle used for collection of refuse by the city. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-52. - Dead animals. 
Small dead animals will be collected by the city during operating hours of the city/county landfill or hauling station, provided the body is appropriately wrapped and isolated in an area readily accessible to the collector. Owners of large dead animals shall be responsible for their removal and disposal. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-53. - Building materials. 
The city shall not be responsible for the collecting preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of a new building, alteration or additions to an existing building or of any kind of construction of any and all refuse, trash, debris resulting therefrom as well as from demolition of existing structures. Such material shall be removed by the owner of the property or by the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-54. - Contagious disease refuse. 
The removal of clothing, bedding or other refuse from some or other places where highly infectious diseases have prevailed shall be decontaminated prior to removal under the supervision and direction of the county health department. Such refuse shall not be placed in receptacles or bulk container for the city collection until decontaminated. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-55. - Hypodermic instruments. 
No person shall dispose of or discard any hypodermic needle or any instrument or device for making hypodermic injections before first breaking, disassembling, destroying or otherwise rendering inoperable and incapable of re-use, such hypodermic syringe, needle, instrument or device, and without safeguarding the disposal thereof, by securely placing in a plastic container with lid so as to avoid the possibility of causing injury to the collection personnel. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-56. - Cardboard boxes, cartons and tires. 
All cardboard boxes, cartons and tires are to be disposed of at designated recycling centers. The person disposing of any such boxes or cartons or the person in charge of the premises shall collapse all cardboard boxes and cartons. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Secs. 58-57—58-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 58-70. - [Enforcement.] 
The city manager or his designee shall investigate complaints or violations of any provisions of this article. They shall determine if there has been a violation, issue warnings, and initiate an attempt to obtain compliance with this article by the person in violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-71. - Initiation of complaint. 
The city manager or his designee shall be authorized to sign a complaint or issue a summons against a violator of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-72. - Civil remedies. 
In case of any violation of this article, the city manager or his designee and the city attorney, in addition to any other remedies, may institute injunction, mandates, or other appropriate proceedings to prevent such violation, or to correct or abate such violation. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Sec. 58-73. - Suspension of service. 
Upon appropriate notice to the person violating this chapter, the city manager or his designee may suspend any service or the use of any facility maintained by the city during the period such violation continues to exist. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
DIVISION 1. - CIVIL PENALTY 

Sec. 58-74. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating this article may be held liable for damages, and the recovery shall be in a sum of not less than $110.00, nor more than $550.00 for each violation. The city attorney may institute a proceeding in any court having jurisdiction thereof to collect such civil penalty. If the violation has been committed by the owner of the property on which the violation occurs, the city clerk may further proceed to collect the costs to the city of eliminating, removing or cleaning the premises in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
DIVISION 2. - CRIMINAL PENALTY 

Sec. 58-75. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in Section 1-12 upon conviction. Provided, however, the foregoing shall not apply to any occupant who fails to remove a cart by 8:00 a.m. on the day after the assigned collection date for garbage pickup. Rather, such occupant shall be subject to a fine of $10.00 per day until the cart is removed. Provided further, the provisions regarding carts shall not apply to any businesses within the city that have been approved by the city manager to utilize dumpsters. 
(Ord. No. 396, 4-4-00) 
Chapter 62 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Streets, § 4.101 et seq. 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; fire lanes, § 34-61 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 38; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; offenses, ch. 50; signs, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 58; traffic and vehicles, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 74; vehicles for hire, ch. 78; subdivision regulations, app. A; zoning, app. B. 
State Law reference— Authority to construct and maintain streets and roads, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; power of city to open, close or extend public streets, alleys and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; executions for collection of assessments for paving streets and laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Permit to dig in streets—Required. 
No person shall make any excavation or opening or dig any ditch, trench, tunnel or hole in, along, across or under any street, sidewalk or other public place for the purpose of laying or placing therein any pipe, wires, poles or for any other purposes, unless a written permit therefor has been issued by the mayor and council. A permit shall not be required where this work is performed under a contract with the city but if this work requires a sidewalk or street to be wholly or partially obstructed, the person shall notify the city clerk, the public works department and the police department at least two hours before obstructing the sidewalk or streets, unless prevented by sudden emergency. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1001) 
State Law reference— Obstructing, encroaching on, or injuring public roads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1. 
Sec. 62-2. - Same—Application; fee. 
All persons desiring a permit in order to make an opening in any street or sidewalk, as set forth in section 62-1, shall make written application therefor, which application shall show the location of the proposed opening, the purpose therefor and the approximate number of square yards of surface to be cut. This application shall be accompanied by a fee established by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1002) 
Sec. 62-3. - Same—City indemnified. 
Any person obtaining a permit as provided for in sections 62-1 and 62-2 agrees as a condition of the issuance of the permit to indemnify and hold harmless the city against any claims or expenses, including attorney's fees, for bodily injury or property damage for accidents or occurrences arising out of the person's operations. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1003) 
Sec. 62-4. - Refilling, repair or excavation. 
When any part of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place of the city shall be torn or dug up for any purpose, the person making this excavation or opening shall have the duty of refilling the excavation or opening so as to restore it to essentially the same condition that existed prior to the excavation or opening and this refilling shall be done in accordance with the standards and specifications issued by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1004) 
Sec. 62-5. - Protection, safety precautions at excavation site. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who obtains a permit under this chapter to do any excavation of any kind which may create or cause a dangerous condition in or near any street, alley, sidewalk or public place of the city without placing and maintaining proper guardrails and signal lights or other warnings at, in or around it, sufficient to warn the public of the excavation or work, and to protect all persons using reasonable care from injuries. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1005) 
Sec. 62-6. - Supervision and control of work; inspections. 
All excavations and work in streets, sidewalks, alleys or public places of the city shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager, whose duty it shall be to inspect them from time to time during the progress thereof. Upon the completion thereof, he shall make a final inspection and see that the street, sidewalk or public place is restored to a condition as good in all respects as before the excavation or work was made or done, and that all debris, materials, tools and equipment are removed therefrom. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1006) 
Sec. 62-7. - Planting of trees. 
All shade trees in the city shall be planted not less than ten feet from the inside line of the sidewalks. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2001) 
Sec. 62-8. - Encroachments on sidewalks, etc. —Prohibited. 
No person shall erect any fence, railing, steps, platform, portico or other obstruction beyond the line designating the limit of the land appropriated or condemned as streets or public highways, and thus encroach upon the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2002) 
State Law reference— Obstructing sidewalks or other public passages, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43. 
Sec. 62-9. - Same—Failure to remove. 
Any person who has erected or is erecting these encroachments on streets, sidewalks or alleys shall be notified to remove them, and upon failure to comply with the requirements of the notice within 24 hours thereof, the chief of police shall have them removed, and the city clerk shall issue an execution against the person so offending for the amount expended in having them removed. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2003) 
Sec. 62-10. - Displaying goods on sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to display any wares, goods or merchandise of any kind upon any part of a city sidewalk except under the following conditions and limitations: 
(1)  Local merchants having a current business license issued by the city, pursuant to section 18-27, may have the use of city sidewalks to display and sell merchandise on the first Thursday, Friday and Saturday of each month. 
(2)  Merchants using the sidewalks shall maintain a clearance of six feet from the outer edge of the sidewalk closest to the street. 
(3)  Entrances and exits to and from buildings which abut the sidewalks shall be at all times kept free, clear and passable for use by pedestrians and emergency personnel. 
(4)  All merchants wishing to use the sidewalks during the above-stated times must file written application with the city manager at least one week prior to the proposed sale, but no sooner than four weeks prior to the proposed sale. 
(5)  The city manager shall issue a permit upon the following conditions being met: 
a.  The applicant must demonstrate that he holds a current business license issued by the city pursuant to section 18-27. 
b.  The applicant must present a writing signed by an agent of his insurance carrier stating that the applicant currently carries premises liability insurance in an amount equal to or exceeding $500,000.00 and that any accident or mishap occurring as a result of applicant's displaying any wares, goods or merchandise of any kind upon any part of a city sidewalk is covered under the primary liability coverage. 
c.  The applicant must execute an indemnity contract between himself and the city in which he agrees to indemnify and save harmless the city from any and all liability resulting from applicant's displaying any wares, goods, or merchandise of any kind upon any part of a city sidewalk. 
(6)  A merchant using city sidewalks pursuant to this section may use only that portion of the sidewalk directly in front of his own store, and may not in any way encroach upon the sidewalk frontage directly in front of any other store or business. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2004; Ord. No. 255, 8-20-85; Ord. No. 276, 6-9-87; Ord. No. 279, § 6-2004, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 333, § 1, 5-17-94) 
Sec. 62-11. - Obstructing streets; construction. 
No person shall deposit, place or put, or cause to be deposited, placed or put, any vehicle of any kind, or any goods, wares, boxes, barrels, casks, logs or any other obstruction in or upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city, so as to obstruct the free passage and use thereof. This section shall not be construed as to prohibit the use of streets, alleys and sidewalks for delivering goods, wares and merchandise or other hauling where this use is necessary, nor shall it prohibit the use thereof for hauling, moving or transporting building material about the premises where building is being done, provided this obstruction shall be as little 
as possible, and only when and so long as necessary. Before building or remodeling in close proximity to the sidewalk, a passageway shall be constructed so as to leave the sidewalk unobstructed and provide safe and easy passage. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2005) 
Sec. 62-12. - Obstruction of railroad crossings by railroad company. 
It shall be unlawful for any railroad company or its employees to obstruct with any train, engine, cars or otherwise any of the public railroad crossing within the city for a longer period than five minutes unless they are in continuous motion. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2006) 
Sec. 62-13. - Awnings. 
No person shall erect, or permit to be erected or keep any awnings over any sidewalk in any business district or zone in the city which awnings are supported by posts placed upon the sidewalk or street. No person shall erect any other type of awnings over the sidewalks without first having made application for a building permit and having received a permit from the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2007) 
Sec. 62-14. - Playing ball games on streets prohibited. 
No person shall play any ball game on any of the streets of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2017) 
Sec. 62-15. - Driving through street barricade. 
No person shall drive any vehicle into or upon any alley or street that has been barricaded by an employee of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2019) 
Sec. 62-16. - Unlawful removal of barricade. 
No person, other than an employee of the city, shall remove any barricade which has been erected by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2020) 
Sec. 62-17. - Felling trees. 
It shall be unlawful to fell trees so as to obstruct the streets, alleys and lanes of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2021) 
Sec. 62-18. - Provisions saved from repeal. 
Section 6-2022 of the 1976 Code regulating signs is not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the city. 
Sec. 62-19. - Street numbers. 
(a)  Posting required. The owner or owners of the fee simple title to or a life estate or estate for years in any real estate upon which there is situated a residence, business or other building or structure to which there is assigned a street number by the city shall post the street number of such business, residence or other building or structure, in one of the following manners: 
(1)  By affixing the street number to the front of the residence, business, building or other structure in a prominent manner such that the same can be easily viewed from the street or road upon which such residence, business, building or other structure fronts. 
(2)  By incorporating the street number into or onto a sign located on the property, subject however to the city's sign regulations, in such a manner that the same can be easily viewed from the road upon which such residence, business, building or other structure fronts. 
(b)  Size. 
(1)  Residential properties. The size of street numbers posted on property zoned residential shall be a minimum of three inches in height, and shall not exceed six inches in height. 
(2)  Nonresidential properties. The size of street numbers posted on property zoned anything other than residential shall be a minimum of three inches in height and a maximum of one foot in height. 
(c)  Variances. Any person desiring a variance from the size requirement for street numbers set forth in subsection (b) of this section may make application for a variance to the zoning board of adjustment in accordance with section 8-3016-2 of Appendix A of this Code, and shall be governed by the procedures set forth therein. 
(Ord. No. 324, 8-18-92) 
Sec. 62-20. - Liability insurance required for persons trimming and/or felling trees. 
(a)  Insurance required. All persons (as defined in section 1-2 of this Code) who trim or fell trees in the city for money, or other valuable consideration, shall first have in effect liability insurance from an insurance company licensed to do business in the state in an amount equalling or exceeding $100,000.00 per occurrence, to cover any damage to persons or property resulting from any negligence in such person's tree-trimming or felling operation. 
(b)  Proof of insurance. Upon request by the city manager, city clerk, chief of police, or any police officer, any person who has been engaged for the purpose of trimming or felling trees within the city shall present proof that the insurance required under subsection (a) hereof is in effect, and absent such proof, such person shall immediately terminate any and all tree trimming and felling within the city, until such proof is provided. 
(c)  Violations. Violations of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or imprisonment not exceeding six months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 341, §§ 2—4, 6-20-95) 
Sec. 62-21. - Parking, standing or driving in private parking areas after request not to do so—Prohibited. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to adopt by reference the provisions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252(a), as provided for in the enabling legislation set forth in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252(c), in order to prohibit parking, standing, or driving vehicles in private parking areas after being requested not to do so. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a monetary fine [as follows]: 
(1)  Not to exceed $50.00 for the first violation; 
(2)  Not to exceed $100.00 for the second violation; and 
(3)  Not to exceed $150.00 for the third or subsequent violation. 
(Ord. No. 389, 2-15-00) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 389, adopted Feb. 15, 2000, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion as § 62-21 was at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 62-22—62-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARADES AND DEMONSTRATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— The state department of transportation's policy regarding the closing of state roads for parades and group demonstrations is on file in the city clerk's office. 

Sec. 62-41. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Block means that portion of any street lying between its intersections with other streets. 
Group demonstration means any assembly together or concert of action between or among two or more persons for the purpose of protesting any matter or of making known any position or promotion of these persons, or of or on behalf of any organization or class of persons, or for the purpose of attracting attention of this assembly. 
Parade means any assemblage of two or more persons riding in or operating any vehicle in any march, ceremony, show, exhibition or procession of any kind in or upon the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks or other public grounds or places. 
Person means any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association or other organization, whether formal or informal. 
Picket line means any two or more persons formed together for the purpose of making known any position or promotion of these persons, or on behalf of any organization or class of persons. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2008) 
Sec. 62-42. - Permit—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to organize, conduct or participate in any parade, picket line or group demonstration in or upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place within the city unless a permit therefor has been issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2009) 
Sec. 62-43. - Same—Reasons for denial. 
The city manager shall issue a permit for the proposed parade unless he finds that: 
(1)  The parades, picket lines or group demonstrations are to commence before 6:00 a.m. or terminate after 5:00 p.m. 
(2)  The parades or group demonstrations are to be held at the same time and place as those designated in a permit issued pursuant to a written application previously received by the city manager. 
(3)  The conduct of the parade will substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(4)  The conduct of the parade will require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement of the parade and of contiguous areas so that adequate police protection cannot be provided the remainder of the city. 
(5)  The conduct of the parade will require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances so that adequate ambulance service to portions of the city not occupied by the parade and contiguous areas will be prevented. 
(6)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will substantially interfere with adequate fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(7)  The conduct of the parade is reasonably likely to result in violence to persons or property causing serious harm to the public. 
(8)  The parade is to be held for the primary purposes of advertising a product, good or event, and is designed to be held primarily for private profit. 
(9)  The conduct of the parade will interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment to such an extent that adequate fire protection cannot be provided to the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2010) 
Sec. 62-44. - Same—Conditions of issuance. 
The city manager shall issue parade permits as required in section 62-43, and in the issuance thereof he shall: 
(1)  Require a written application for permit to be filed not less than 24 hours in advance of the parade, picket line, or group demonstration which application shall specify the time and place for the commencement of the picket line and the time, place, route and duration of the parade or group demonstration. 
(2)  Require that the application for a permit specify whether or not minors will be permitted to participate. 
(3)  Require that the application for a permit shall specify and the permit shall designate the person or persons in charge of the activity. This person shall accompany the parade, picket line or group demonstration and shall carry the permit with him at the time. The permit shall not be valid in the possession of any other person. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2011) 
Sec. 62-45. - Certain activities prohibited. 
The following acts or activities, when performed or undertaken in conjunction with, or as a part of, any parade, picket line or group demonstration, are hereby prohibited and declared unlawful: 
(1)  The carrying on or about the person of any firearm, or any weapon or article, including but not limited to blackjacks, nightsticks or flashlights which by their use might constitute a deadly weapon. 
(2)  The taking or keeping of any dog or other vicious animal, whether leashed or unleashed. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2012) 
Sec. 62-46. - Revocation of permit. 
The city manager shall revoke any permit granted for a parade, picket line or group demonstration for any of the following causes: 
(1)  The violation by any participant of section 62-45. 
(2)  The failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the permit. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2013) 
Sec. 62-47. - Interference prohibited. 
No person shall hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade, picket line or group demonstration being conducted under authority of a permit duly issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2014) 
Sec. 62-48. - Additional regulations applicable to picketing. 
Picket lines and picketing shall be subject to the following additional regulations: 
(1)  Picketing may be conducted only on the sidewalks reserved for pedestrian movement and may not be conducted on the portion of a street used primarily for vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Not more than ten pickets promoting the same objective shall be permitted to use either of the two sidewalks within a single block at any one time. 
(3)  Pickets may carry written or printed placards or signs not exceeding two feet in width and two feet in length promoting the objective for which the picketing is done; provided, the words used are not derogatory or defamatory in nature. 
(4)  Pickets must march in single file and not abreast and must not march closer together than 15 feet, except in passing one another. Pickets shall not be allowed to walk more than five feet from the curbline and shall be in continuous motion. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2015) 
Sec. 62-49. - Exceptions. 
This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; or 
(2)  Any governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1976, § 6-2016) 
Secs. 62-50—62-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL EVENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 416, §§ 1—23, adopted March 7, 2003, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as article III, §§ 62-71—62-93 is at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 62-71. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
City manager means the manager of the city of Sylvania, Georgia, or his designee for the administration of this chapter. 
Producer means any person, group of persons, organization, association, club, or other entity responsible for planning, producing and conducting an event. 
Special event or event means any organized activity having as its purpose entertainment, recreation and/or education, such as a festival or celebration, foot or vehicle race, parade or march, rally or assembly which takes place on a public street, sidewalk or right-of-way, or occurs on private property and impacts government services on public rights-of-way. 
Vendor means any person or persons who engage in the sale to the public of any food or food products, goods, services, or merchandise of whatever nature from any location, either mobile or stationary, on a temporary itinerant basis on any public street, sidewalk, or right-of-way. The definition of vendor, as used in this article, shall not be construed to include or prohibit a permanent business, operating under the provisions of the business license ordinance and other applicable laws, from displaying goods or merchandise on a public sidewalk immediately in front of and adjacent to the permanent business structure so long as such displays do not impede the normal flow of pedestrian traffic and so long as other laws and ordinances pertaining to such business or displays are complied with. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 1, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-72. - Permits. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to conduct or cause to be conducted any special event in the city without having obtained a valid permit for such event. 
(b)  Geographic limitation; responsibility for police and sanitation service. A special event shall be limited to the specific geographic area(s) within which the event is to take place and the producer of a special event shall be responsible for the provision of police and sanitation services within the boundaries of the event for a period of one hour past the conclusion of the event or until the area is cleared of all activities and structures related to such event. 
(c)  Time limitation. Except for clearing of the area, no special event shall be allowed to continue beyond the time approved on the permit for the event. 
(d)  Delineation of boundaries; preservation of areas for circulation. The outermost boundaries of the special event shall be fully and clearly delineated on a map, which shall be no smaller than 8½ × 11 inches in size, and attached to the application for a permit. All public streets and/or sidewalks within and adjacent to such area(s) shall be clearly identified. The city manager, or designee, shall require, as part of the approval for the event, that areas no less than five feet in width shall be designated and preserved for public circulation and access to adjoining business establishments outside the area(s) delineated for the event. 
(e)  Maps for walks or runs. The producer of a special event such as a walk or run, as to which the provisions of subsection (d) above would not be practicable, shall submit with the application for a permit a map, which shall be no smaller than 8½ × 11 inches in size, showing the exact route of the course for the walk or run. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 2, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-73. - Application; fee. 
(a)  A producer of a special event shall make application for a permit for such event at the office of the city manager on a form prescribed by the city manager. Application forms may be obtained from the office of the city manager, the office of the city clerk, and the police department. 
(b)  An application for a special event should be filed at least 30 days prior to the date the event is scheduled to occur. However, no application shall be accepted earlier than one year prior to the date of the event. 
(c)  A nonrefundable application fee of $25.00 shall be paid at the time the application for a permit is filed. Such fee shall be payable to the city by cash, money order, or cashier's check. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 3, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-74. - Identification of producer. 
The producer of an event, if a group or organization, shall be fully identified on the application. However, a special event permit shall be issued only to an individual person, who may be the actual producer or a designated agent of the producer, and such individual person shall be solely and fully responsible for compliance with all provisions, including all financial requirements, of this chapter and other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 4, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-75. - Administrative review. 
The city manager shall cause the application to be circulated to each government department and/or other agency whose services the city manager determines would be affected by the nature and activities of the proposed event. Each such department or agency shall review the application and note the services which it will be required to perform, the number of personnel to perform such services, the length of time to perform such services, the cost to perform such services, and any other information which would assist the city manager in facilitating the event and services required. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 5, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-76. - Special conditions on permit. 
Each department of the government reviewing an application may recommend in writing certain conditions or restrictions as deemed necessary to facilitate the event, to comply with other laws or regulations, and/or to the safety, health and welfare of the community. In reviewing the recommendations of the departments, the city manager may impose such conditions or restrictions as a part of the permit and such special conditions so imposed shall be construed to have the full force and effect of law as a provisions of this chapter. A violation of such conditions or restrictions shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 6, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-77. - Final approval of permit; minimum review. 
(a)  The city manager is authorized to approve and issue a permit for a special event after considering all comments and conditions of the reviewing departments and agencies as well as other information pertaining to the proposed event as described on the application, and after the payment of all applicable fees and costs. 
(b)  A minimum of 15 working days shall be allowed for the administrative review of an application and the issuance of a permit. 
(c)  The government shall either issue or deny the permit no later than 30 working days following the date the completed application is filed. If the permit is denied, the producer shall be notified in writing of the denial and the reason(s) for the denial. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 7, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-78. - Emergency issuance of permit. 
In extraordinary circumstances, the city manager or the chief of police, as his designee, shall be authorized to waive or otherwise expedite any or all of the review process and to issue a special event permit upon payment by the producer of all applicable fees and costs for such event. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 8, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-79. - Permit fees. 
The fee for a permit to conduct a special event shall be based on all services to be provided by the government for such event and shall be equal to the estimated actual cost to the government to provide such services. The initial permit fee shall be the aggregate of the estimated costs of such services calculated by each government department. If, at the conclusion of the event, the cost of government services is greater than the initial payment, the producer of the event shall be billed for the difference. Failure to pay the outstanding amount within 30 days of the billing date shall be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 9, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-80. - Liability. 
The producer of any special event shall hold harmless the city, its officers, employees and agents from liability of damages arising from any acts or omissions emanating from a special event. Proof of such waiver shall be filed with, and made a part of, the application form. The producer shall be responsible for providing any and all other insurance that may be necessary for any special event. The amount and kind of insurance required shall be determined by the city manager, or his designee, after considering the nature of the special event, and the potential for harm and the degree of harm to persons and property. The producer shall provide proof to the city manager, or his designee, that such insurance is in effect prior to the issuance of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 10, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-81. - Vendors. 
(a)  Sales permitted. The sale of food, or any merchandise or services of any type by a vendor shall be allowed as a component of a special event provided such vendor is approved and authorized in writing by the producer of the event and shall be conducted in accordance with such conditions and limitations as shall be imposed in writing by the producer and submitted as part of the application for a permit. 
(b)  Authorization of vendors. The producer of a special event shall have sole responsibility and authority to allow or disallow sidewalk or street vending as a component of an event. Such identification shall be not less than three inches, shall state that the bearer is an official participant in the event, and shall bear the signature of the producer of the event. 
(c)  Identification required. Any vendor authorized by the event producer shall be required to prominently display on his or her person a badge identifying the vendor as an authorized participant in the event. Such identification shall be not less than three inches by three inches, shall state that the bearer is an official participant in the event, and shall bear the signature of the producer of the event. 
(d)  Permit not required. Vendors authorized by the producer of an event as a component of the event shall not be required to obtain any separate vendors permit to operate during the period of the event. However, all other vendors, of whatever nature, not authorized as a participant in the special event shall obtain the appropriate licenses and permits as required under other applicable ordinances. 
(e)  Unauthorized vending prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any vendor not authorized by the producer of a special event as provided under this section to engage in such business within a distance of 25 yards of such event from one hour before until one hour after the event. 
(f)  Food sales. The vendor of any food, whether hot or cold, as a part of a special event shall be subject to all rules and regulations of the county health department. It shall be the responsibility of the producer of an event to assure compliance with this section by any such vendors. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 11, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-82. - Glass containers prohibited. 
The use of glass containers within the area of any special event shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 12, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-83. - Police services. 
Traffic and crowd control shall be provided by the city police department and/or the county sheriff's department, and the number of officers and/or special arrangements shall be determined by the chief of police of the city. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 13, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-84. - Toilet facilities. 
The producer of a special event shall be required to provide temporary outdoor toilet facilities at any event at which 200 or more persons are expected to be in attendance. The number of toilets and their locations shall be determined by the director of the building inspection department. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 14, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-85. - Tents, stages, etc. 
Tents, arbors, stages, grandstands or other temporary facilities constructed or erected as a part of a special event shall be approved by the city building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 15, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-86. - Street closing. 
The complete or partial closure of any street, sidewalk or other public way as a part of a special event shall be approved by the city manager in consultation with the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 16, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-87. - Banners, signs, etc. 
Temporary, noncommercial banners or signs may be permitted overhead across public streets for the purpose of designating "starting" and "finish" lines for a race. Small banners, pennants, signs or other decorations which do not interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and which do not damage or deface any tree or public structure, may be allowed as part of a special event. Approval of the building inspection department shall be obtained by the event producer for any banners or signs permitted in this section. The producer of the event shall be responsible for the removal of such banners, pennants or decorations within 48 hours after the close of the event. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 17, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-88. - Duration of permit. 
No permit issued under this article shall be valid prior to or past the date of the special event for which it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 18, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-89. - Cessation of activities. 
The safety, health, welfare and good order of all citizens and the community shall be first and foremost and every special event shall be conducted in such manner. The chief of police may terminate any activity, whether a part of or the entire event, which does not meet this community standard. Upon notification of the event producer in person by the chief of police to cease any activity, it shall be unlawful for such producer and/or any participants to permit such activity to continue. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 19, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-90. - Picketing and demonstrations, etc. 
Any person, group or organization engaged in any picketing, demonstrations, assembly, gathering, procession or other activity protected by the U. S. Constitution shall be prohibited from blocking the ingress and egress of any public or private place. Any person, group or organization engaged in such activities is required to make application as set forth in Section 6-5-3(a). However, any such person, group or organization shall be exempt from the permit requirement in O.C.G.A. § 6-5-2 and the fees set forth in O.C.G.A. §§ 6-5-3(c) and 6-5-9. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 20, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-91. - Funeral processions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to any parade or procession conducted under the supervision and direction of a funeral director in conjunction with any funeral. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 21, 3-7-03) 
Sec. 62-92. - Penalties. 
Any violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding $500.00, and/or imprisonment of not more than six months. 
(Ord. No. 416, § 22, 3-7-03) 
Chapter 66 - TAXATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1—66-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES 

Sec. 66-26. - Dates due and delinquent. 
All ad valorem taxes on property within the corporate limits of the city shall be due on October 1 of each calendar year and shall be considered delinquent and become in default on December 20 of each calendar year. 
(Code 1976, § 2-4031) 
Sec. 66-27. - Taxes in default. 
After ad valorem taxes become in default, the city clerk shall then issue tax execution therefor, which shall be collected or levied as provided by the charter of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 2-4032) 
Secs. 66-28—66-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSE FEES AND TAXES ON INSURERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— County and municipal corporation tax on life insurance companies based on gross direct premiums, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; county and municipal corporation tax on other than life insurance companies based on gross direct premiums, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. 

Sec. 66-51. - Annual license fee levied. 
There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon insurance companies doing business within the city in the amount of $40.00, for the privilege of engaging in the business of insurance within the city. There shall be an additional annual license fee in the same amount for each separate business location in excess of one, operated and maintained by such company within the city. For the purpose of this article, the term "insurance company" shall mean those companies authorized to sell those five classes of insurance set forth in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. 
(Ord. No. 232, 10-4-83; Ord. No. 250, § I, 4-16-85) 
Sec. 66-52. - Additional fee for separate business. 
There is hereby levied an additional annual license fee of $14.00 on each insurance company for each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee under this article, which company is operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or sales involving term financing, offers, solicits or taking applications for insurance through licensed agents of insurance companies for insurance. 
(Ord. No. 232, 10-4-83; Ord. No. 250, § II, 4-16-85) 
Sec. 66-53. - Deduction of fee from state premium taxes. 
Life insurance companies within O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1) may deduct from the premium taxes otherwise payable to the state under O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4, in addition to all credits and abatements allowed by law, the license fee imposed pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 250, § III, 4-16-85) 
Sec. 66-54. - Independent life insurance agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. 
There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which a life insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 66-51, in the amount of $40.00 for each such location within the city. 
(Ord. No. 232, § 3, 10-4-83) 
Sec. 66-55. - Gross premiums tax on life insurers. 
There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the city in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed in section 66-51. 
(Ord. No. 232, § 4, 10-4-83) 
Sec. 66-56. - Gross premiums tax on all other insurers. 
There is hereby levied an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business 
(Ord. No. 232, § 5, 10-4-83) 
Secs. 66-57—66-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS BUSINESS LICENSE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authorization to levy and collect a business license tax from depository financial institutions, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 

Sec. 66-76. - Levy. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 there is hereby levied an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations, state building and loan associations a business license tax at the rate of .25 percent of the gross receipts of the institutions. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institutions pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. 
(b)  For purposes of this section "gross receipts" shall be the same as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 and shall mean the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized below during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax imposed by this article is due. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 2, 12-27-83; Ord. No. 286, 2-16-88) 
Sec. 66-77. - Calculation of gross receipts—Banks. 
Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: 
(1)  Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others. 
(2)  Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions. 
(3)  Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under agreements of resale. 
(4)  Interest on other bonds, notes, and debentures, excluding interest on obligations in the state or its political subdivisions and obligations on the United States. 
(5)  Dividends on stocks. 
(6)  Income from direct lease financing. 
(7)  Income from fiduciary activities. 
(8)  Service charges on deposit accounts. 
(9)  Other service charges, commissions and fees. 
(10)  Other income. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 2(A), 12-27-83; Ord. No. 286, 2-16-88) 
Sec. 66-78. - Same—Savings and loan associations. 
Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: 
(1)  Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold in service for others. 
(2)  Interest on mortgages, participations or mortgage-backed securities. 
(3)  Interest on real estate sold on contract. 
(4)  Discounts on mortgage loans purchased. 
(5)  Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States. 
(6)  Interest and dividends on investments and deposits. 
(7)  Loan fees. 
(8)  Loan servicing fees. 
(9)  Other fees and charges. 
(10)  Gross income from real estate owned operations. 
(11)  Net income from office building operations. 
(12)  Gross income from real estate held for investment. 
(13)  Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries. 
(14)  Miscellaneous operating income. 
(15)  Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans and other assets. 
(16)  Miscellaneous nonoperating income. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 2(B), 12-27-83; Ord. No. 286, 2-16-88) 
Sec. 66-79. - Deductions from gross receipts. 
The following items shall be deducted from gross receipts calculated pursuant to section 66-77 or 66-78 of this article: 
(1)  An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period. 
(2)  An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 7-1-730 through 7-1-734. 
(3)  An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions. 
(4)  An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than Georgia. 
(5)  To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subsections (2), (3) and (4) of this section, any deductions taken under subsection (1) of this section shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subsections (2) through (4) of this section bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subsections (1) through (4) above. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 2(C), 12-27-83; Ord. No. 286, 2-16-88) 
Sec. 66-80. - Filing of return. 
Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. The returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 3, 12-27-83; Ord. No. 286, 2-16-88) 
Sec. 66-81. - Due date. 
The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be April 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 3, 12-27-83) 
Secs. 66-82—66-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOTEL AND MOTEL EXCISE TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 439, adopted December 19, 2006, amended article V in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article V pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 281, § 1—10, 12, adopted November 3, 1987. 
State Law reference— County and municipal excise taxes on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.; operators of hotels, inns and roadhouses, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-1 et seq. 

Sec. 66-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, shall be defined as follows: 
City. The City of Sylvania is empowered to impose a hotel-motel excise tax pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
City clerk means the duly appointed city clerk of the city or his designee. 
Due date means the twentieth day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. 
Estimated tax liability means the lodging provider's prospective tax liability based upon the average monthly tax remittance in the prior fiscal year, as adjusted for change in tax rate or substantial change in circumstances due to damage to the hotel. 
Folio means primary documentation produced by a hotel that demonstrates interaction between the lodging provider and the occupant, and which, at a minimum, reflects the name and address given by the occupant, the date(s) of occupancy, the amount of rent charged for each date together with the amounts of applicable excise tax(es), and the method(s) of payment. 
Guest room means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for transient occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Hotel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any lodging house, rooming house, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, truck stop, tourist cabin, lodge, inn, time-share or other condominium, apartment community, public club, or private club, containing guest rooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by paying guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor, or otherwise. It does not include any hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, jail, prison, or other buildings in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
Lodging provider means any person operating a hotel in the city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sub-lessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person operating such hotel; and who is subject to the taxation imposed for furnishing for value to the public any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations. 
Monthly period means the calendar months of any year. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any guest room or apartment in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any guest room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Permanent resident means any occupant who, as of a given date, has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guest room in a hotel for not less than ten continuous days next preceding such date. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint adventure, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, cooperative, estate trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number; excepting the United States, the state and any instrumentality of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the lodging provider to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Tax means the tax on occupants imposed by this article, as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 439, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 66-102. - Tax rate. 
There shall be paid for every occupancy of a guest room in a hotel in the city a tax at the rate of five percent of the amount of rent unless an exemption is provided under section 66-104. 
(Ord. No. 439, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 66-103. - Collection of tax by lodging provider. 
Every lodging provider renting guest rooms in the city shall collect a tax of five percent on the amount of rent from the occupant unless an exemption is provided under section 66-104. The lodging provider shall provide a receipt to each occupant, which receipt shall reflect both the amount of rent and the amounts of this and other applicable tax(es). This tax shall be due from the occupant, and shall be collected by the lodging provider at the same time that the rent is collected. The lodging provider shall be liable for any amount of tax that he fails to collect appropriately; and must remit to the city any amount of tax collected in excess of that which should have been collected. 
(Ord. No. 439, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 66-104. - Exemptions. 
No tax shall be collected from an occupant after becoming a permanent resident; or from an occupant who certifies in writing that he is staying in such accommodations as a result of his residence having been destroyed by fire or other casualty; or from the United States and the State of Georgia or any instrumentality of either thereof; or from any official employee of state, its units of local government or any other instrumentality of the state, when traveling on official business and presenting written substantiation thereof or paying by state or local government credit or debit card; or from a foreign diplomat exempted by treaty or consular convention, when presenting substantiation issued by the United States Department of State. Occupancy provided without charge in money or otherwise is exempt from this tax. 
(Ord. No. 439, 12-19-06) 
Sec. 66-105. - Registration of lodging provider; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. 
Every person engaging or about to engage in business as a lodging provider in the city shall immediately register with the city clerk on a form provided by said official. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place(s) of business and such other information which would facilitate the administration of the tax as prescribed by the city clerk. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. The city clerk shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each lodging provider to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of a lodging provider. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. 
(Ord. No. 439, 12-19-06)
