ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 78-1—78-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS 

Sec. 78-26. - Application for license. 
Any person owning a taxicab and desiring to operate it within the city must first make application to the mayor and council in the following form, the terms and conditions of which are made a part of this article: 
"To the mayor and council of the City of Sylvania. 
Gentlemen: 
I (or we) hereby apply for a license to operate a public taxicab (or taxicabs) in Sylvania for the year beginning June 1, 19 ____________ . If I (we) am (are) granted this license I (we) pledge to observe all traffic laws of the city, and I (we) also pledge that I (we) will not use my (our) taxicab(s) for transporting passengers for immoral purposes, or for transporting any intoxicating beverages. I (we) understand that if I (we) violate any of the above regulations that the mayor and council may revoke my (our) license. (Here give the following information: make of car; number of passengers that can be carried; state license number; driver's license number; name of insurance company insured with and amount of property damage, liability and bodily injury liability insurance.) 
(Applicant's Signature)" 
(Code 1976, § 6-1051) 
Sec. 78-27. - Liability insurance. 
A copy of the applicant's liability insurance policy must be filed with the city clerk before the taxicab license is issued. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1052) 
Sec. 78-28. - Revocation of license. 
Should any owner of any taxicab permitted to operate under this article fail to meet all of the requirements stated herein, the mayor and council may revoke his license and retain the money paid therefor. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1053) 
APPENDIX A - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; signs, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62. 

ARTICLE I. - AUTHORITY AND JURISDICTION 

Section 8-2001. - Authority. 
In pursuance of the authority granted by the Georgia General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957, No. 358, as amended, the mayor and council hereby enacts and ordains as follows. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 11, 11-5-68) 
State Law reference— Ga. Code Ann., § 69-12. 
Section 8-2002. - Jurisdiction. 
The provisions of this chapter shall govern all subdivision of land within the corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 12, 11-5-68) 
Charter reference— Regulation of street locations, division 1, section 1.105(19). 
Sections 8-2003—8-2010. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE AND SHORT TITLE 

Section 8-2011. - Purpose. 
To encourage the development of an economically sound and stable community; to assure the provision of required streets, utilities and other facilities and services to new land developments; to assure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in new land developments; to assure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in new land developments to the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes; to assure, in general, the wise development of areas in harmony with the master plan of the community; and to secure equitable handling of all subdivision plans by providing uniform procedures and standards for observance both of the subdivider and the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 21, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2012 - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known as and may be cited as the "Land Subdivision Regulations, City of Sylvania, Georgia." 
(Ord. No. 110, § 22, 11-5-68) 
Sections 8-2013—8-2020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEFINITION OF TERMS 

Section 8-2021. - General definitions. 
Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this chapter shall carry their customary dictionary meanings. For the purpose of this chapter, certain words or terms used herein are defined as follows: 
City means the City of Sylvania, Georgia. 
City council means the city council for the City of Sylvania, Georgia. 
Mayor and council means the mayor and council of Sylvania, Georgia. 
Words used in the present tense include the future tense. 
Words used in the singular include the plural, and words used in the plural include the singular. 
The word "shall" is always mandatory. 
The word "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company or corporation as well as an individual. 
The word "lot" includes the word "plot" or "parcel." 
The word "building" includes the word "structure." 
The word "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied." 
(Ord. No. 110, § 31, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 1, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2022. - List of definitions. 
Cul-de-sac means a dead end street where there is room for a vehicle to turn at a circular end. 
Master plan (same as comprehensive plan) means any part or element of the overall plan for development adopted by the planning commission as provided by the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957, No. 358, as amended. 
Street means, relates to and includes streets and avenues, boulevards, roads, highways, expressways, lanes, alleys and other ways. For the purpose of this chapter, streets are classified by function as follows (see following page): 


Major street means those indicated as such on the major street plan map, which serve primarily as major traffic ways for travel through and within the city. 
Collector street means those streets which serve as feeders to a major street, as collectors of traffic from minor streets and for circulation around a residential neighborhood. 
Minor street means those streets provided for the primary purpose of furnishing access to abutting properties. 
Subdivider means an individual, firm, association, syndicate, partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity (or agent therefor) that undertakes the activities covered by these regulations. Inasmuch as the subdivision plat is merely a necessary means to the end of assuring a satisfactory development, the term "subdivider" is intended to include the terms "developer" and "builder" even though the persons involved in successive stages of the project may vary. 
Subdivision means a subdivision shall be construed to be a division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites or divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of conveyance, transfer, improvement, sale, legacy or building development, and includes all division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision, and where appropriate to the context relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or areas subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: 
The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards set forth in this chapter. 
The division of land into parcels of five acres or more where no new street is involved. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 32, 11-5-68) 
Sections 8-2023—8-2030. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PREAPPLICATION 

Section 8-2031. - Preapplication consultation. 
Whenever the subdivision of a tract of land within the city is proposed, the subdivider is urged to consult early and informally with the planning commission. The subdivider may submit sketch plans and data showing existing conditions within the site and its vicinity, and the proposed layout and development of the subdivision. The purpose of the preapplication review is to facilitate the subsequent preparation of plans, and no fees are charged for this review. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. IV, 11-5-68) 
Sections 8-2032—8-2040. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND DESIGN STANDARDS FOR SUBDIVISIONS 

Section 8-2041. - Conformance to major street plan. 
All streets and other features of the major street plan shall be platted by the subdivider in the location and to the dimensions indicated on the major street plan adopted by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 51, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2042. - Public sites and open spaces. 
When a proposed school site or other public building site, park or other land for public uses is located in whole or in part in the subdivision, the planning commission may require that, as a prerequisite to plat approval, these sites shall be dedicated or reserved by the subdivider for acquisition by the appropriate public agency. 
Areas for parks, playgrounds or other public uses shall be of reasonable size. No arbitrary percentage of areas shall be insisted upon by the planning commission but, in general, developers shall set aside not less than five percent of the area for these purposes. 
If, in the opinion of the planning commission, an area greater than five percent is deemed necessary for recreational purposes, the planning commission shall refuse to approve the plat until sufficient land is dedicated for this public purpose. 
Where, in the opinion of the planning commission, a public area may not be suitable within the proposed subdivision, the subdivider may be required to furnish an in-lieu cash payment to provide for the acquisition of land which will serve the proposed subdivision. 
Whenever a plat proposes the dedication of land to public use that the planning commission finds not required or suitable for this public use, the planning commission shall refuse to approve the plat. 
The approval of a plat by the planning commission shall not be deemed to constitute or effect an acceptance by the city of the dedication of any street or other grounds shown upon the plat. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 52, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2043. - Subdivision names. 
The name of the subdivision shall not duplicate or too closely approximate the name of any other subdivision within the city. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 53, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2044. - Suitability of land. 
Land subject to flooding and land deemed by the commission to be uninhabitable shall not be platted for residential occupancy nor for such other uses as may increase danger to health, life or property, or aggravate the flood hazard, but this land within the plat shall be set aside for such uses as shall not be endangered by periodic or occasional inundation or shall not produce unsatisfactory living conditions. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 54, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2045. - Large parcels. 
In case a tract is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots, these parcels shall be arranged so as to allow the opening of future streets and logical future resubdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 55, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2046. - Lots. 
Lots shall front upon a public street. Lot lines shall be generally perpendicular or radial to street lines. Lot dimensions shall meet the requirements of the comprehensive zoning ordinance for the district or districts in which the subdivision is located. Corner lots shall be increased in size wherever necessary so as to provide that any structure to be placed thereon shall conform to the minimum setback line of each street as required in the comprehensive zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 56, 11-5-68) 
Cross reference— Zoning section 8-3001 et seq. 
Section 8-2047. - Blocks. 
The length shall not exceed 1,200 feet or be less than 400 feet and the width sufficient to provide for two tiers of lots, but irregularly shaped lots indented by cul-de-sac streets and containing interior parks will be acceptable when properly designed, and provision made for maintenance of interior parks. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 57, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2048. - Streets. 
(a)  Conformance to major street plan and other elements of the master plan. The arrangements of streets in the subdivision shall provide for the continuation of the principal streets in adjoining subdivisions or for their proper projection when adjoining property has not yet been subdivided, and in general, conform to the master plan. 
(b)  Street names. Street names shall require the approval of the planning commission. Streets that are obviously in alignment with streets already existing and named shall be given the name of the existing street. Names of new streets shall not duplicate or closely approximate those of existing streets. 
(c)  Street jogs. Street jogs with center line of off-sets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. (See below) 
(d)  Existing street jogs. Where development is proposed on an existing street which jogs or offsets less than 125 feet, these streets shall be realigned before development is permitted. 
(e)  Dead end or cul-de-sac streets. Dead end or cul-de-sac streets shall not be greater in length than 500 feet. They shall be provided at the closed end with a turn-around having a property line radius of at least: 50 feet with an outside pavement radius of at least 40 feet. (See below) 
(f)  Alleys. Alleys may be required at the rear of all lots used for multi-family, commercial or industrial developments, but shall not be provided in one- and two-family residential developments unless the subdivider provides evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys. 
(g)  Reserve strips. Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys and public grounds shall not be permitted unless the control is placed in the hands of the mayor and council under conditions approved by the planning commission. 
(h)  Street intersections. Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersection shall be at an angle of less than 60 degrees unless required by unusual circumstances. (See below) 
(i)  Curb radii. Curb radii at street intersections shall be at least 25 feet. Where the angle of street intersection is less than 90 degrees, a radius of at least 30 feet shall be required. 
(j)  Easements. Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided where necessary for utilities or drainage. 
(k)  Double frontage lots. Except under special conditions, double frontage lots shall be avoided. Where the planning commission under special conditions permits double frontage lots, the frontage along the rear lot lines shall be screened with a masonry wall, or evergreen hedge at least five feet in height. 



(Ord. No. 110, § 58, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2049. - Geometric standards and other requirements of streets. 

 
* Major streets shall meet all requirements shown on the major thoroughfare plan. (See following page) 

(Ord. No. 110, § 59, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2050. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS IN SUBDIVISIONS 

Section 8-2051. - Approval of preliminary plat required. 
Construction of improvements shall not commence until the preliminary plat has been approved. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. VI, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2052. - Improvements installed by subdivider. 
The subdivider shall be required to install or have installed at his expense the following improvements: 
(1)  Monuments. Two concrete monuments at least 36 inches in length and four inches square with a suitable center point at each street intersection on the right-of-way line and iron pin monuments three-fourths inches in diameter and 24 inches long at all points on boundary lines of lots where there is a change in direction, and at all lot corners. 
(2)  Streets. At least one and one-half inches of hot plant mix asphalt (or, if Georgia DOT specifications are more stringent, such specifications shall be met) on a base of at least six inches thickness of compacted Class "A" or "B" sand-clay or top soil, or equivalent or crush and run (or, if Georgia DOT specifications are more stringent, such specifications shall be met). No final grading or paving of the street, or construction or installation of utilities in the bed of a street, shall be permitted until the grade has been officially established. No paving shall begin until the compacted base has been inspected and approved by the official representative of the city and underground utilities installed and approved. 
(3)  Water mains. 
a.  Where a public water main is within 1,500 feet of the subdivision at its nearest point, the subdivision shall be connected with such water main in the manner hereafter provided. In such cases, mains of at least six inches shall be required, unless the engineering consultants regularly employed by the city shall approve a lesser diameter. The City of Sylvania shall bear the expense of materials and labor in installing such water main from the existing public water main to the property line of the subdivision. In extending water mains within the subdivision, the subdivider shall purchase all required materials, but the City of Sylvania will bear the expense of installing such lines. Where a public water main is not reasonably accessible as determined by the planning commission, the subdivider shall provide an individual water supply according to the standards of the City of Sylvania or the Screven County Health Department, and the most restrictive standard shall apply. 
b.  In installing water mains as herein provided, the materials shall be of such composition and nature as shall be approved by the consultant engineers of the city. Notwithstanding any conflicting provision of the charter of the City of Sylvania and its code of ordinances, it shall be acceptable to use polyvinylchloride, otherwise known as PVC pipe. 
(4)  Sanitary sewers. Wherever a public sanitary sewer is within 1,500 feet of the subdivision at its nearest point and connection by gravity flow is feasible, the subdivider shall connect with this sanitary sewer and provide a connection for each lot. The size of the mains shall be at least eight inches. The subdivider shall be responsible for the costs of all taps, lift pump stations, manholes and extensions to existing municipal facilities. Where sanitary sewers are not available, an oxidation pond, septic tank or other disposal devise designed and installed according to standards of the city or the county health department may be permitted, and the most restrictive standards shall apply. 
(5)  Storm sewers. Storm sewers, catch basins and traps or adequate drainage ditches or cross ditches shall be provided in each subdivision. They shall be designed to carry not less than the storm water from a rainfall expected to occur once in ten years with a runoff factor of 90 percent for pavements and buildings and a variable runoff factor depending on the topography of the ground for other areas. Storm drainage design shall be based upon Talbot's formula. 
(6)  Variance or other improvements. Where the subdivider can show that a provision of these regulations would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, and where, because of topographical or other conditions peculiar to the site, in the opinion of the planning commission a departure may be made without destroying the intent of these provisions, the planning commission may authorize a variance. Likewise, if because of peculiar conditions or circumstances relative to a particular subdivision, the planning commission may require the installation of sidewalks, street trees or other improvements. Any variance thus authorized or additional improvement thus required is to be stated in writing in the minutes of the planning commission with the reasoning on which the variance or addition was justified as set forth. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 61, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 174, § 1, 5-18-76; Ord. No. 231, 9-20-83; Ord. No. 414, § 2, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2053. - Improvements to be installed by city. 
(a)  Street name markers. Street name markers shall be provided at the corners of all street intersections. 
(b)  Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants shall be installed so as to comply with the latest requirements necessary to maintain the city's class rating for fire insurance purposes. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 62, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 231, 9-20-83) 
Sections 8-2054—8-2060. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Section 8-2061. - Submission of plat. 
Following the preapplication consultation of a proposed land subdivision, the subdivider shall submit to the city council the following: 
(1)  The preliminary plat and other documents as specified hereafter; 
(2)  A letter requesting review and approval of the preliminary plat and giving the name and address of a person to whom the notice of a hearing by the city council on the preliminary plat shall be sent; and 
(3)  A preliminary plat filing fee of $15.00 unless the plat contains five or less lots in which case the fee shall be $2.00 per lot. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 71, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 3, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2062. - Review of preliminary plat. 
(a)  Review by planning commission. The planning commission shall review the preliminary plat for conformance to the rules and regulations of this chapter, and the requirements of the zoning ordinance, and shall take into consideration the general requirements of the community and the best use of the land to be subdivided. The preliminary plat may be approved, disapproved or approved subject to modifications. The commission may indicate the specific changes required, and the public improvements which must be provided as required by this chapter, or the amount of the performance bond therefor which it will require as a prerequisite to the approval of the final plat. 
(b)  Recommendation to city council. If the planning commission approves the preliminary plat, it shall forward the same to the Sylvania City Council for final approval. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 72, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 4, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2063. - Notice of hearing on preliminary plat. 
The city council shall hold a hearing on the preliminary plat within 45 days of receiving the same from the planning commission. Notice of the time and plat of the hearing shall be sent by the city clerk by registered or certified mail to the person designated in the letter requesting preliminary review and approval, not less than five days before the date fixed therefor. If action is not taken within 45 days after the hearing, the preliminary plat shall be deemed approved and a certificate of approval issued on demand. The subdivider may waive the 45 day time limit and consent to an extension of time. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 73, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 5, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2064. - Tentative and conditional nature of preliminary plat approval. 
Tentative and conditional approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plat. Rather, it shall be deemed an expression of approval of the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final plat which will be submitted for approval of the planning commission and city council and for recording upon fulfillment of the requirements of these regulations and the stipulations in the conditional approval, if any. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 74, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 6, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2065. - Expiration of tentative approval of preliminary plat. 
The tentative approval shall expire after one year unless an extension of time is granted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 75, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 7, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2066. - Preliminary plat specifications. 
The preliminary plat shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Number of copies. Five copies of the preliminary plat shall be furnished by the subdivider: One copy to be retained in the files of the planning commission, one copy to be submitted to the county health department, one copy to be submitted to the Sylvania Public Works Department, one copy to be reviewed by appropriate city and county officials and the postmaster, and one copy to be returned to the subdivider. 
(2)  Form. The preliminary plat shall be drawn clearly and legibly at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet or larger. The sheet size shall be not less than 16 by 24 inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 76, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2067. - Data required on preliminary plat. 
The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Proposed subdivision name or identifying title and acreage to be subdivided. 
(2)  Name and address of owner of record, subdivider and owners of adjoining property. 
(3)  Date, graphic scale and north point. 
(4)  Contours at an interval of not greater than five feet and such street cross sections and profiles as may be required by the planning commission. Where the land is relatively flat, spot elevations at intervals sufficient to show the drainage pattern, shall be plotted. Elevations of monuments or other permanent fixed points shall be noted. 
(5)  Exact boundaries of the tract to be subdivided by distances and bearings. 
(6)  Existing and proposed easements and their approximate location, width and distances. 
(7)  Names and dimensions of existing and proposed streets and alleys on and adjacent to the tract. 
(8)  Location and type of existing and proposed sewerage and storm drainage and water supply facilities and other utilities on or adjacent to the tract, showing proposed connections. 
(9)  Lot lines with approximate dimensions and lot numbers. 
(10)  Sites, if any, and their acreages, to be reserved or dedicated for public uses. 
(11)  Vicinity map showing location of subdivision and its relationship to the rest of the city and surrounding countryside. This may be shown at a smaller scale. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 77, 11-5-68) 
Sections 8-2068—8-2070. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - FINAL PLAT 

Section 8-2071. - Certificates of approval required. 
After tentative approval of the preliminary plat and before approval of the final plat, there shall be filed with the planning commission by the building inspector and all other departments of the city and county concerned with the requirements of subdivisions, certificates as to the satisfactory completion of all improvements required, and for any requirements not so completed, a certificate by the city attorney as to the sufficiency of the bond offered in lieu thereof. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. VIII, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2072. - Procedure for final plat approval. 
The subdivider shall submit to the city council the following: 
(1)  The final plat and other documents as specified hereafter. 
(2)  A letter requesting review and approval of the final plat and giving the name and address of a person to whom the notice of a hearing by the city council on the final plat shall be sent. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 81, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 8, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2073. - Review of final plat. 
(a)  Review by planning commission. The planning commission shall review the final plat for conformance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat and with the rules and regulations of this chapter. The final plat may be approved, disapproved or approved subject to modifications. 
(b)  Recommendation to city council. If the planning commission approves the final plat, it shall forward the same to the city council for final approval. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 82, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 9, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2074. - Notice of hearing on final plat. 
The city council shall hold a hearing on the final plat within 45 days of receiving the same from the planning commission. Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be sent by the city clerk by registered or certified mail to the person designated in the letter and on the plat, requesting review and approval, not less than five days before the date fixed therefor. After the hearing, notation of the action taken shall be made on each of the five required copies of the plat. If action is not taken within 45 days of the hearing, the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval issued on demand. The subdivider may waive the 45 day limit and consent to an extension of time. The ground of disapproval of any plat shall be stated in the minutes of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 83, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 10, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2075. - Recording of final plat. 
Upon approval of the final plat, with the signature of the secretary of the planning commission, the signature of the mayor or mayor pro tem, and the signature of the city clerk thereon, the developer shall have the plat recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county. The subdivider shall have responsibility for payment of the recording fee. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 84, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 11, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2076. - Final plat specifications. 
The final plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the preliminary plat and certain additional specifications as follows: 
(1)  The final plat shall be drawn in permanent ink on tracing cloth or mylar base film. 
(2)  The final plat shall be drawn at a scale of 100 feet or less equals one inch. Profiles shall be drawn at a horizontal scale of 100 feet equals one inch and a vertical scale of five feet equals one inch. The size of the sheet shall not exceed 42 inches in any one dimension. Separate sectional sheets may be submitted if necessary. 
(3)  Exact location and description of monuments. 
(4)  Exact locations, widths and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat. 
(5)  Street center lines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii and lengths of tangents. 
(6)  Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest one-tenth-foot and bearings. 
(7)  Lots numbered in numerical order and blocks lettered alphabetically. 
(8)  Locations and dimensions of all improvements constructed or installed. 
(9)  Private convenants or restrictions, if any, shall either be recorded on the final plat or on an identified document attached to the final plat. 
(10)  Certification by a registered professional engineer or land surveyor stating that the plan represents a survey made by him and that all the monuments as shown thereon actually exist, and that their location, size and material are correctly shown. A certified copy of computation and closure shall be submitted by the engineer or land surveyor. 
(11)  Owner's certification that he has approved plat and will comply with all regulations and requirements of the planning commission. 
(12)  Certificate of dedication of all streets, utilities, rights-of-way, easements and public areas to the city. 
(13)  Space for signatures of chairman and secretary of the planning commission if plat is approved. 
(14)  Space for signatures of mayor and city clerk if plat is approved by mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 85, 11-5-68) 
Sections 8-2077—8-2080. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Section 8-2081. - Plat approval. 
After this chapter shall have been put into effect, any subdivision that fails to meet the requirements of this chapter shall be disapproved by the planning commission and/or city council. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 91, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 12, 3-4-03) 
Section 8-2082. - Recording of plats. 
No plat of a subdivision lying within the corporate limits of the city shall be recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county unless it has been given final approval by the planning commission and city council and the description by metes and bounds on the instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from these requirements. No plat shall be recorded that does not bear the signature and seal of a registered land surveyor. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 92, 11-5-68; Ord. No. 414, § 13, 3-4-03) 
State Law reference— Improper filing or use of plats, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-9905. 
Section 8-2083. - Sale or transfer of lots. 
The subdivider of any land within the city who transfers or sell or agrees to sell or negotiates to sell such land by reference to or exhibition of or by other use of a plat of subdivision of such land before such plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court shall be guilty of a misdemeanor (Section 19 of the Georgia General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957). 
(Ord. No. 110, § 93, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2084. - Acceptance of streets. 
No public authority shall accept, improve or maintain any street not shown on an approved and recorded final plat unless this street has received the legal status of a public street. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 94, 11-5-68) 
Section 8-2085. - Building permit. 
No building permit shall be issued and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lots within the city unless the street giving access to the lots is a public street. Any building erected in violation of these provisions is an unlawful structure and the building inspector, city attorney or other agent of the city shall enjoin this erection or cause the building to be vacated or removed. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 95, 11-5-68) 
APPENDIX B - ZONING[1]

Editor's note— Printed herein is the city's zoning ordinance, as adopted by the city council on November 3, 1992, and effective on November 3, 1992. Amendments to the ordinance are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines, capitalization, citation to state statutes, and expression of numbers in text has been used to conform to the Code of Ordinances. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets.
